sections.text: (1) This Act may be called the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023. (2) It shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, appoint, and different dates may be appointed for different provisions of this Sanhita. (3) Every person shall be liable to punishment under this Sanhita and not otherwise for every act or omission contrary to the provisions thereof, of which he shall be guilty within India. (4) Any person liable, by any law for the time being in force in India, to be tried for an offence committed beyond India shall be dealt with according to the provisions of this Sanhita for any act committed beyond India in the same manner as if such act had been committed within India. (5) The provisions of this Sanhita shall also apply to any offence committed by— (a) any citizen of India in any place without and beyond India; (b) any person on any ship or aircraft registered in India wherever it may be; (c) any person in any place without and beyond India committing offence targeting a computer resource located in India. (6) Nothing in this Sanhita shall affect the provisions of any Act for punishing mutiny and desertion of officers, soldiers, sailors or airmen in the service of the Government of India or the provisions of any special or local law.
sections.simple: This section establishes the name of the law and states that the government decides when it starts[cite: 26, 27]. It applies to everyone within India, Indian citizens abroad, anyone on Indian ships or planes, and those targeting Indian computers from outside the country[cite: 34, 36, 37, 38]. It does not override laws regarding military desertion or specific local/special laws[cite: 43].

sections.text: In this Sanhita, unless the context otherwise requires,— (1) "act" denotes as well a series of acts as a single act; (2) "animal" means any living creature, other than a human being; (3) "child" means any person below the age of eighteen years; (4) "counterfeit"... (5) "Court" means a Judge... (6) "death" means the death of a human being... (7) "dishonestly" means doing anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person; (8) "document"... includes electronic and digital record... (9) "fraudulently"... (10) "gender"... includes transgender... (11) "good faith"... (12) "Government"... (13) "harbour"... (14) "injury"... (15) "illegal"... (16) "Judge"... (17) "life"... (18) "local law"... (19) "man"... (20) "month" and "year"... (21) "movable property"... (22) "number"... (23) "oath"... (24) "offence"... (25) "omission"... (26) "person"... (27) "public"... (28) "public servant"... (29) "reason to believe"... (30) "special law"... (31) "valuable security"... (32) "vessel"... (33) "voluntarily"... (34) "will"... (35) "woman"... (36) "wrongful gain"... (37) "wrongful loss"... (38) "gaining wrongfully" and "losing wrongfully"... (39) words and expressions used but not defined in this Sanhita but defined in the Information Technology Act, 2000 and the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in that Act and Sanhita.
sections.simple: This section provides 39 specific definitions used throughout the law [cite: 44-154]. Key updates include defining a 'child' as under 18 [cite: 47], including 'transgender' under gender [cite: 73], and expanding 'documents' to include digital and electronic records[cite: 54]. It also defines legal terms like 'dishonestly', 'public servant', and 'voluntarily'[cite: 53, 103, 142].

sections.text: (1) Throughout this Sanhita every definition of an offence, every penal provision, and every Illustration of every such definition or penal provision, shall be understood subject to the exceptions contained in the Chapter entitled "General Exceptions"... (2) Every expression which is explained in any Part of this Sanhita, is used in every Part of this Sanhita in conformity with the explanation. (3) When property is in the possession of a person's spouse, clerk or servant, on account of that person, it is in that person's possession within the meaning of this Sanhita. (4) In every Part of this Sanhita, except where a contrary intention appears from the context, words which refer to acts done extend also to illegal omissions. (5) When a criminal act is done by several persons in furtherance of the common intention of all, each of such persons is liable for that act in the same manner as if it were done by him alone... (7) Wherever the causing of a certain effect... is an offence, it is to be understood that the causing of that effect partly by an act and partly by an omission is the same offence... (9) Where several persons are engaged or concerned in the commission of a criminal act, they may be guilty of different offences by means of that act.
sections.simple: This section explains how to interpret the law. It states that all crimes are subject to the 'General Exceptions' chapter[cite: 155, 156]. It introduces the 'Common Intention' rule: if a group commits a crime together, every member is equally responsible[cite: 170]. It also clarifies that 'acts' include 'illegal omissions' (failing to do something you are legally required to do)[cite: 169].

title: BNS: Chapter II. Of Punishments
category: Types of punishments, commutation of sentences, and rules for fines and confinement

sections.text: The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Sanhita are— (a) Death; (b) Imprisonment for life; (c) Imprisonment, which is of two descriptions, namely:— (1) Rigorous, that is, with hard labour; (2) Simple; (d) Forfeiture of property; (e) Fine; (f) Community Service.
sections.simple: This section lists the six types of legal penalties in India: the death penalty, life imprisonment, standard imprisonment (either hard labor or simple), seizing of property, monetary fines, and the newly introduced community service [cite: 208-216].

sections.text: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute any punishment under this Sanhita to any other punishment in accordance with section 474 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023. Explanation.—For the purposes of this section the expression "appropriate Government" means.— (a) in cases where the sentence is a sentence of death or is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the Union extends, the Central Government; and (b) in cases where the sentence (whether of death or not) is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends, the Government of the State within which the offender is sentenced.
sections.simple: The government has the power to reduce or change a person's sentence to a less severe one without needing the person's permission[cite: 217]. [cite_start]The Central Government handles cases involving death sentences or federal laws, while State Governments handle cases involving state-level laws [cite: 218-221].

sections.text: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years unless otherwise provided.
sections.simple: When the law needs to calculate a fraction of a sentence (like 'half of the maximum punishment'), a life sentence is treated as being 20 years long for calculation purposes[cite: 222].

sections.text: In every case in which an offender is punishable with imprisonment which may be of either description, it shall be competent to the Court which sentences such offender to direct in the sentence that such imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, or that such imprisonment shall be wholly simple, or that any part of such imprisonment shall be rigorous and the rest simple.
sections.simple: A judge can decide if a jail sentence will involve hard labor (rigorous), no labor (simple), or a specific mix of both for different parts of the sentence[cite: 223].

sections.text: (1) Where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend, the amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive. (2) ...it shall be competent to the Court... to direct by the sentence that, in default of payment of the fine, the offender shall suffer imprisonment for a certain term... (3) The term... shall not exceed one-fourth of the term of imprisonment which is the maximum fixed for the offence... (5) If the offence is punishable with fine or community service, the imprisonment... shall be simple, and... shall not exceed,— (a) two months when the amount of the fine does not exceed five thousand rupees; (b) four months when the amount of the fine does not exceed ten thousand rupees; and (c) one year in any other case.
sections.simple: Fines must not be excessive even if the law doesn't set a limit[cite: 224]. [cite_start]If someone doesn't pay a fine, the court can order extra jail time[cite: 228]. [cite_start]This extra time generally cannot exceed 1/4th of the original maximum jail term [cite: 232][cite_start], or ranges from 2 months to 1 year for crimes only punishable by fine [cite: 234-237].

sections.text: (1) Where anything which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the punishment of more than one of such his offences, unless it be so expressly provided. (2) ...the offender shall not be punished with a more severe punishment than the Court which tries him could award for any one of such offences.
sections.simple: If a single crime is made up of several smaller acts that are also crimes (like a beating made of many individual blows), the person is punished for the whole crime once, not for every single part [cite: 248, 266-268].

sections.text: In all cases in which judgment is given that a person is guilty of one of several offences specified in the judgment, but that it is doubtful of which of these offences he is guilty, the offender shall be punished for the offence for which the lowest punishment is provided if the same punishment is not provided for all.
sections.simple: If a court is sure a person committed a crime but isn't sure which specific one (out of a few possibilities), the person must be given the lightest (lowest) possible punishment among those options[cite: 270].

sections.text: Whenever any person is convicted of an offence for which under this Sanhita the Court has power to sentence him to rigorous imprisonment, the Court may... order that the offender shall be kept in solitary confinement... not exceeding three months in the whole... (a) a time not exceeding one month if the term of imprisonment shall not exceed six months; (b) a time not exceeding two months if the term... shall not exceed one year; (c) a time not exceeding three months if the term... shall exceed one year.
sections.simple: For crimes involving hard labor, a court can order solitary confinement[cite: 271]. [cite_start]The maximum total time is 3 months, based on the length of the sentence: 1 month for short sentences, 2 months for up to a year, and 3 months for long sentences [cite: 272-274].

sections.text: In executing a sentence of solitary confinement, such confinement shall in no case exceed fourteen days at a time, with intervals between the periods of solitary confinement of not less duration than such periods; and when the imprisonment awarded shall exceed three months, the solitary confinement shall not exceed seven days in any one month...
sections.simple: Solitary confinement cannot be used all at once. [cite_start]It is limited to 14 days at a time with equal breaks in between[cite: 275]. [cite_start]If the sentence is longer than 3 months, the person can only be in solitary for 7 days per month[cite: 276].

sections.text: Whoever, having been convicted by a Court in India, of an offence punishable under Chapter X or Chapter XVII of this Sanhita with imprisonment... for a term of three years or upwards, shall be guilty of any offence punishable under either of those Chapters with like imprisonment... shall be subject for every such subsequent offence to imprisonment for life, or to imprisonment... which may extend to ten years.
sections.simple: Repeat offenders who commit serious crimes involving property or currency (under Chapters X and XVII) face much harsher punishments, including life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison for their subsequent crimes[cite: 277].

title: BNS: Chapter III. General Exceptions
category: Situations where an act is not considered a crime

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith believes himself to be, bound by law to do it.
sections.simple: An act is not a crime if the person was legally required to do it, or if they honestly believed they were required to do it because of a misunderstanding of the facts (but not a misunderstanding of the law).

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a Judge when acting judicially in the exercise of any power which is, or which in good faith he believes to be, given to him by law.
sections.simple: A judge cannot be charged with a crime for actions taken while performing their official duties, provided they are acting within their legal power or honestly believe they are.

sections.text: Nothing which is done in pursuance of, or which is warranted by the judgment or order of, a Court; if done whilst such judgment or order remains in force, is an offence, notwithstanding the Court may have had no jurisdiction to pass such judgment or order, provided the person doing the act in good faith believes that the Court had such jurisdiction.
sections.simple: An act done following a court order is not a crime, even if the court didn't actually have the authority to give that order, as long as the person following it believed in good faith that the court was authorized.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by any person who is justified by law, or who by reason of a mistake of fact and not by reason of a mistake of law in good faith, believes himself to be justified by law, in doing it.
sections.simple: An act is not a crime if the law allows it, or if the person honestly thought the law allowed it due to a factual mistake.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by accident or misfortune, and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.
sections.simple: A pure accident is not a crime if it happened while doing something legal, in a legal way, with proper care, and without any intention to cause harm.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence merely by reason of its being done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause harm, if it be done without any criminal intention to cause harm, and in good faith for the purpose of preventing or avoiding other harm to person or property.
sections.simple: Doing something that might cause harm is not a crime if it was done without bad intent and solely to prevent a much greater harm from happening.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.
sections.simple: Children under the age of seven cannot be held criminally responsible for any act.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve years of age, who has not attained sufficient maturity of understanding to judge of the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion.
sections.simple: Children between 7 and 12 are not responsible for a crime if they aren't mature enough to understand what they were doing or that it was wrong.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
sections.simple: An act is not a crime if the person, due to mental illness, did not understand what they were doing or did not know it was against the law.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, is, by reason of intoxication, incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong, or contrary to law; provided that the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.
sections.simple: A person is not responsible for a crime committed while intoxicated if they were drugged or forced to drink against their will and didn't know what they were doing.

sections.text: In cases where an act done is not an offence unless done with a particular knowledge or intent, a person who does the act in a state of intoxication shall be liable to be dealt with as if he had the same knowledge as he would have had if he had not been intoxicated, unless the thing which intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will.
sections.simple: If you get drunk voluntarily, the law assumes you have the same knowledge of your actions as a sober person. You only get a pass if the intoxication was forced upon you.

sections.text: Nothing which is not intended to cause death, or grievous hurt, and which is not known by the doer to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause... to any person, above eighteen years of age, who has given consent...
sections.simple: If an adult consents to a risk (like a sport), and you don't intend to kill or seriously injure them, you aren't responsible for accidental harm caused during that activity.

sections.text: Nothing, which is not intended to cause death, is an offence by reason of any harm... to any person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, and who has given a consent...
sections.simple: A doctor performing surgery with the patient's consent is not a criminal for any harm caused, as long as they acted in good faith for the patient's benefit and didn't intend to cause death.

sections.text: Nothing which is done in good faith for the benefit of a person under twelve years of age, or person of unsound mind, by, or by consent... of the guardian... is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause...
sections.simple: Guardians can give consent for medical or beneficial acts for children under 12 or mentally ill persons; the person performing the act is protected from criminal charges for harm caused in good faith.

sections.text: A consent is not such a consent as is intended by any section of this Sanhita, (a) if the consent is given by a person under fear of injury, or under a misconception of fact... (b) if the person... is unable to understand the nature and consequence... (c) if the person is under twelve years of age.
sections.simple: Consent is invalid if it's obtained through fear, lies, mental incapacity, or if the person is under 12 years old.

sections.text: The exceptions in sections 25, 26 and 27 do not extend to acts which are offences independently of any harm which they may cause...
sections.simple: You can't use 'consent' as an excuse for acts that are illegal on their own, regardless of whether someone agreed to them (like causing a miscarriage illegally).

sections.text: Nothing is an offence by reason of any harm which it may cause to a person for whose benefit it is done in good faith, even without that person's consent, if the circumstances are such that it is impossible for that person to signify consent...
sections.simple: In an emergency where a person can't give consent (like being unconscious), a doctor or helper can act in good faith to save them without being charged for harm caused.

sections.text: No communication made in good faith is an offence by reason of any harm to the person to whom it is made, if it is made for the benefit of that person.
sections.simple: If a doctor tells a patient bad news in good faith and for their benefit, and the shock causes the patient harm, the doctor is not a criminal.

sections.text: Except murder, and offences against the State punishable with death, nothing is an offence which is done by a person who is compelled to do it by threats, which... reasonably cause the apprehension that instant death to that person will otherwise be the consequence...
sections.simple: If someone forces you to commit a crime (other than murder or treason) by threatening to kill you instantly, you are not responsible. However, this doesn't count if you joined a criminal gang voluntarily.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence by reason that it causes... any harm, if that harm is so slight that no person of ordinary sense and temper would complain of such harm.
sections.simple: The law doesn't care about 'trifles'—harm so small that a reasonable person wouldn't bother complaining about it.

sections.text: Nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence.
sections.simple: Acts done to protect yourself or others within the limits of the law are not crimes.

sections.text: Every person has a right... to defend (a) his own body, and the body of any other person... (b) the property... of himself or of any other person, against any act which is an offence falling under the definition of theft, robbery, mischief or criminal trespass...
sections.simple: You have the right to use force to protect your body (or someone else's) from injury, and your property (or someone else's) from crimes like theft or trespassing.

sections.text: When an act, which would otherwise be a certain offence, is not that offence, by reason of the youth, the want of maturity... the unsoundness of mind or the intoxication... every person has the same right of private defence against that act which he would have if the act were that offence.
sections.simple: You have the right to defend yourself even if the person attacking you isn't legally responsible for their actions (like a child or a mentally ill person).

sections.text: (1) There is no right of private defence,— (a) against an act which does not reasonably cause the apprehension of death or of grievous hurt, if done... by a public servant acting in good faith... (c) in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities.
sections.simple: You can't claim self-defense against a police officer doing their job (unless you fear they will kill or seriously injure you), nor can you use force if you have enough time to call the police for help.

sections.text: The right of private defence of the body extends... to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the assailant, if the offence... be of any of the descriptions... (a) apprehension that death will otherwise be the consequence... (c) intention of committing rape... (g) throwing or administering acid...
sections.simple: You are allowed to kill an attacker in self-defense if you reasonably believe they are about to kill you, cause serious injury, commit rape, kidnap someone, or throw acid.

sections.text: If the offence be not of any of the descriptions specified in section 38, the right of private defence of the body does not extend to the voluntary causing of death... but does extend... to the voluntary causing... of any harm other than death.
sections.simple: If the threat isn't one of the extreme ones listed in Section 38, you can defend yourself but you are not allowed to kill the attacker.

sections.text: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises... and it continues as long as such apprehension... continues.
sections.simple: Your right to defend yourself starts the moment you feel threatened and ends once the danger has passed.

sections.text: The right of private defence of property extends... to the voluntary causing of death... if the offence... be... (a) robbery; (b) house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise; (c) mischief by fire... (d) theft, mischief, or house-trespass... causing apprehension that death or grievous hurt will be the consequence...
sections.simple: You can kill someone to protect property only in extreme cases like robbery, house-breaking at night, burning down a building, or if you fear you will be killed while protecting the property.

sections.text: If the offence... be theft, mischief, or criminal trespass, not of any of the descriptions specified in section 41, that right does not extend to the voluntary causing of death, but does extend... to... any harm other than death.
sections.simple: For simple theft or trespassing, you can use force to protect your property, but you are not allowed to kill the person.

sections.text: The right of private defence of property,— (a) commences when a reasonable apprehension of danger to the property commences; (b) against theft continues till the offender has effected his retreat... or the property has been recovered...
sections.simple: The right to protect property starts when the danger starts and lasts until the thief runs away, you get the police's help, or you get your stuff back.

sections.text: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
sections.simple: If you have to defend yourself against a deadly attack and an innocent person might get hurt in the process (like firing into a mob to stop a killer), you are not a criminal for taking that risk.

title: BNS: Chapter IV. Of Abetment, Criminal Conspiracy and Attempt
category: Rules regarding helping, planning, or trying to commit a crime

sections.text: A person abets the doing of a thing, who— (a) instigates any person to do that thing; or (b) engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that thing... or (c) intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that thing.
sections.simple: A person is guilty of abetment if they encourage someone to commit a crime, join a plan (conspiracy) to do it, or help in any way (including by staying silent when they should have acted).

sections.text: A person abets an offence, who abets either the commission of an offence, or the commission of an act which would be an offence, if committed by a person capable by law of committing an offence with the same intention or knowledge as that of the abettor.
sections.simple: You are an abettor if you help someone commit a crime, even if the person you helped isn't legally capable of committing a crime themselves (like a child or someone mentally ill).

sections.text: A person abets an offence within the meaning of this Sanhita who, in India, abets the commission of any act without and beyond India which would constitute an offence if committed in India.
sections.simple: If you are in India and you help or plan a crime that takes place in another country, you are treated as if the crime happened in India.

sections.text: A person abets an offence within the meaning of this Sanhita who, without and beyond India, abets the commission of any act in India which would constitute an offence if committed in India.
sections.simple: If you are outside India and you help or plan a crime that happens inside India, you are guilty of abetment under Indian law.

sections.text: Whoever abets any offence shall, if the act abetted is committed in consequence of the abetment, and no express provision is made by this Sanhita for the punishment of such abetment, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence.
sections.simple: If the crime you helped with actually happens, and there isn't a specific rule for your punishment, you get the exact same punishment as the person who committed the crime.

sections.text: Whoever abets the commission of an offence shall, if the person abetted does the act with a different intention or knowledge from that of the abettor, be punished with the punishment provided for the offence which would have been committed if the act had been done with the intention or knowledge of the abettor and with no other.
sections.simple: If you help someone do something bad, but they have a different motive than you, you are punished based on what *you* intended to happen.

sections.text: When an act is abetted and a different act is done, the abettor is liable for the act done, in the same manner and to the same extent as if he had directly abetted it: Provided that the act done was a probable consequence of the abetment...
sections.simple: If you help someone commit one crime, but they end up committing a different one that was a likely result of your help, you are responsible for that new crime too.

sections.text: If the act for which the abettor is liable under section 51 is committed in addition to the act abetted, and constitute a distinct offence, the abettor is liable to punishment for each of the offences.
sections.simple: If the person you helped commits the crime you planned *plus* another related crime, you can be punished for both.

sections.text: When an act is abetted with the intention on the part of the abettor of causing a particular effect, and an act... causes a different effect from that intended... the abettor is liable for the effect caused... provided he knew that the act abetted was likely to cause that effect.
sections.simple: If you help someone cause harm, and the result is worse than you planned (like death instead of just an injury), you are responsible for the worse result if you knew it was a possibility.

sections.text: Whenever any person, who is absent would be liable to be punished as an abettor, is present when the act or offence for which he would be punishable... is committed, he shall be deemed to have committed such act or offence.
sections.simple: If you helped plan a crime and you are actually there when it happens, the law treats you as if you did the crime yourself.

sections.text: Whoever abets the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, shall, if that offence be not committed... be punished with imprisonment... for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine...
sections.simple: If you help or plan a very serious crime (like murder) but it doesn't actually happen, you still face up to 7 years in prison. If someone gets hurt during the attempt, you face up to 14 years.

sections.text: Whoever abets an offence punishable with imprisonment shall, if that offence be not committed... be punished with imprisonment... for a term which may extend to one-fourth part of the longest term provided for that offence...
sections.simple: If you help with a crime but it isn't committed, you get 1/4th of the maximum punishment for that crime. If you are a public servant whose job was to prevent that crime, you get 1/2 of the punishment.

sections.text: Whoever abets the commission of an offence by the public generally or by any number or class of persons exceeding ten, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years and with fine.
sections.simple: If you encourage a group of more than 10 people or the general public to commit a crime, you face up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever intending to facilitate... the commission of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, voluntarily conceals by any act or omission, or by the use of encryption... the existence of a design to commit such offence...
sections.simple: If you know about a plan for a major crime and you hide it—including using encryption or secret tools to help it happen—you can be jailed for up to 7 years if the crime happens, or 3 years if it doesn't.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, intending to facilitate... the commission of an offence which it is his duty as such public servant to prevent, voluntarily conceals... the existence of a design to commit such offence...
sections.simple: If a public servant (like a police officer) hides a criminal plan they were supposed to stop, they face severe penalties—up to half of the crime's maximum punishment or up to 10 years for serious crimes.

sections.text: Whoever, intending to facilitate... the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment, voluntarily conceals... the existence of a design to commit such offence...
sections.simple: If you hide a plan for a crime that carries a jail sentence, you can be jailed for 1/4th of the term if the crime happens, or 1/8th if it doesn't.

sections.text: (1) When two or more persons agree with the common object to do... (a) an illegal act; or (b) an act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy...
sections.simple: Criminal conspiracy is when two or more people agree to do something illegal or do something legal using illegal methods. Just agreeing is a crime if the goal is a serious offense; for other goals, some action must be taken toward the plan.

sections.text: Whoever attempts to commit an offence punishable by this Sanhita with imprisonment for life or imprisonment... and in such attempt does any act towards the commission of the offence...
sections.simple: If you try to commit a crime but fail, you are still punished. Generally, you get half of the jail time or fine that the actual crime would have carried.

title: BNS: Chapter V. Of Offences Against Woman and Child
category: Offences relating to sexual violence, marriage, miscarriage, and crimes against children

sections.text: A man is said to commit 'rape' if he— (a) penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (b) inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (c) manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, anus or any part of body of such woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (d) applies his mouth to the vagina, anus, urethra of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions:— (i) against her will; (ii) without her consent; (iii) with her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested, in fear of death or of hurt; (iv) with her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married; (v) with her consent when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent; (vi) with or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age; (vii) when she is unable to communicate consent.
sections.simple: Defines rape as various acts of sexual penetration or contact committed without the woman's voluntary consent, against her will, or through deception/coercion. It includes specific provisions for victims under 18 and those unable to give consent due to mental state or intoxication.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, except in the cases provided for in sub-section (2), commits rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. (2) [Detailed list of aggravated circumstances including rape by police officers, public servants, armed forces, staff of jails/hospitals, relatives, or during communal violence].
sections.simple: Sets the punishment for rape at a minimum of 10 years, extending to life imprisonment. Harsher penalties apply to individuals in positions of trust or authority, such as police, public servants, or medical staff.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, commits rape on a woman under sixteen years of age shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine. (2) Whoever, commits rape on a woman under twelve years of age shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life... and with fine or with death.
sections.simple: Provides severe punishments for the rape of minors: a minimum of 20 years for victims under 16, and a minimum of 20 years to the death penalty for victims under 12.

sections.text: Whoever, commits an offence punishable under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) of section 64 and in the course of such commission inflicts an injury which causes the death of the woman or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life... or with death.
sections.simple: Imposes a minimum of 20 years, life imprisonment, or the death penalty if a rape results in the victim's death or a persistent vegetative state.

sections.text: Whoever has sexual intercourse with his own wife, who is living separately, whether under a decree of separation or otherwise, without her consent, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Criminalizes non-consensual sexual intercourse by a husband with his wife if they are legally separated.

sections.text: Whoever, being in a position of authority or in a fiduciary relationship; or a public servant... abuses such position or fiduciary relationship to induce or seduce any woman... to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment... not less than five years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes individuals in authority who use their position to coerce a woman into sexual intercourse, even if it does not legally qualify as rape.

sections.text: Whoever, by deceitful means or by making promise to marry to a woman without any intention of fulfilling the same, has sexual intercourse with her, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Criminalizes sexual intercourse obtained through deceit, such as a false promise of marriage or suppressing one's true identity.

sections.text: (1) Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of a common intention, each of those persons shall be deemed to have committed the offence of rape and shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years... or for life. (2) Where a woman under eighteen years of age is raped... [punished with life imprisonment or death].
sections.simple: Defines gang rape and mandates a minimum of 20 years in prison for each participant. If the victim is under 18, the penalty increases to life imprisonment or death.

sections.text: Whoever has been previously convicted of an offence punishable under section 64 or section 65 or section 66 or section 70 and is subsequently convicted... shall be punished with imprisonment for life... or with death.
sections.simple: Mandates life imprisonment or the death penalty for repeat offenders of serious sexual crimes.

sections.text: (1) Whoever prints or publishes the name or any matter which may make known the identity of any person against whom an offence under section 64 [to 71] is alleged... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Prohibits the disclosure of a sexual assault victim's identity in the media or public domain, punishable by up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever prints or publishes any matter in relation to any proceeding before a Court with respect to an offence referred to in section 72 without the previous permission of such Court shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Prohibits publishing details of court proceedings regarding sexual offences without court permission.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished with imprisonment... not less than one year but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes actions intended to outrage a woman's modesty with 1 to 5 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) A man committing any of the following acts:— (i) physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures; or (ii) a demand or request for sexual favours; or (iii) showing pornography against the will of a woman; or (iv) making sexually coloured remarks, shall be guilty of the offence of sexual harassment.
sections.simple: Defines sexual harassment and sets punishments ranging from 1 to 3 years in prison depending on the nature of the act.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked, shall be punished with imprisonment... not less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Specifically punishes the act of using force to disrobe a woman with 3 to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed... or disseminates such image shall be punished... [with 1 to 7 years imprisonment].
sections.simple: Defines and punishes voyeurism, including capturing or sharing images of a woman in a private setting without her consent.

sections.text: (1) Any man who— (i) follows a woman and contacts... repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest... or (ii) monitors the use by a woman of the internet... commits the offence of stalking.
sections.simple: Defines stalking as repeatedly following or contacting a woman against her will, or monitoring her electronic communications. Punishment is up to 3 years for the first offense.

sections.text: Whoever, intending to insult the modesty of any woman, utters any words, makes any sound or gesture, or exhibits any object... or intrudes upon the privacy of such woman, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and also with fine.
sections.simple: Punishes verbal or physical gestures and words intended to insult a woman's modesty or privacy.

sections.text: (1) Where the death of a woman is caused by any burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment... in connection with, any demand for dowry, such death shall be called 'dowry death'.
sections.simple: Defines dowry death for suspicious deaths within 7 years of marriage involving dowry harassment. Punishment is 7 years to life imprisonment.

sections.text: Every man who by deceit causes any woman who is not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit or have sexual intercourse with him in that belief, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes men who trick women into cohabiting or having sex by falsely making them believe they are legally married.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Criminalizes bigamy (marrying again while a previous marriage is still valid), except in specific cases of court-declared voids or long-term disappearance.

sections.text: Whoever, dishonestly or with a fraudulent intention, goes through the ceremony of being married, knowing that he is not thereby lawfully married, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes the act of performing a fraudulent or mock marriage ceremony with up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever takes or entices away any woman who is and whom he knows or has reason to believe to be the wife of any other man, with intent that she may have illicit intercourse with any person... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Punishes enticing or detaining a married woman for the purpose of illicit intercourse.

sections.text: Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Criminalizes marital cruelty by a husband or his relatives.

sections.text: For the purposes of section 85, 'cruelty' means— (a) any wilful conduct which is of such a nature as is likely to drive the woman to commit suicide or to cause grave injury... or (b) harassment... with a view to coercing her... to meet any unlawful demand for any property or valuable security.
sections.simple: Defines cruelty as conduct likely to lead to suicide or serious injury, or harassment related to dowry or property demands.

sections.text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled... to marry any person against her will... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes kidnapping or abducting a woman to force her into marriage or illicit intercourse.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall, if such miscarriage be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman, be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Criminalizes causing a miscarriage unless it is done in good faith to save the mother's life.

sections.text: Whoever commits the offence under section 88 without the consent of the woman... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Imposes much harsher penalties (up to life imprisonment) for causing a miscarriage without the woman's consent.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes causing the death of a woman while attempting to cause a miscarriage, with increased penalties if done without her consent.

sections.text: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of thereby preventing that child from being born alive... shall, if such act be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the mother, be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Punishes acts intended to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth, unless done to save the mother.

sections.text: Whoever does any act under such circumstances, that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes causing the death of a 'quick' (moving) unborn child through an act that would otherwise be considered homicide.

sections.text: Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, shall expose or leave such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning such child, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Punishes the abandonment of a child under 12 years of age by a parent or guardian.

sections.text: Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child... intentionally conceals or endeavours to conceal the birth of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Criminalizes the secret disposal of a child's body to hide its birth.

sections.text: Whoever hires, employs or engages any child to commit an offence shall be punished with imprisonment... not less than three years but which may extend to ten years, and with fine.
sections.simple: Punishes using a child to commit crimes, including for sexual exploitation or pornography.

sections.text: Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any child to go from any place... with intent that such child may be... forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Criminalizes inducing a child to go anywhere for the purpose of sexual exploitation.

sections.text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking dishonestly any movable property from the person of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes kidnapping or abducting a child under 10 with the intent to steal from them.

sections.text: Whoever sells, lets to hire, or otherwise disposes of any child with intent that such child shall at any age be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes selling or hiring out a child for prostitution or sexual exploitation.

sections.text: Whoever buys, hires or otherwise obtains possession of any child with intent that such child shall at any age be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse... shall be punished with imprisonment... not less than seven years but which may extend to fourteen years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes buying or hiring a child for the purpose of sexual exploitation with 7 to 14 years in prison.

title: BNS: Chapter VI. Of Offences Affecting the Human Body
category: Offences affecting life, hurt, wrongful restraint, criminal force, and kidnapping

sections.text: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.
sections.simple: Defines culpable homicide as causing death with the intent to kill, intent to cause serious injury likely to kill, or knowledge that the act will likely result in death.

sections.text: Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder,— (a) if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death; or (b) [intent to cause injury known to likely cause death]; or (c) [injury sufficient in ordinary course of nature to cause death]; or (d) [act so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability cause death].
sections.simple: Defines murder as culpable homicide committed with specific intent or extreme knowledge of the danger. It includes exceptions for grave provocation, self-defense, public service duties, sudden fights, and consent.

sections.text: If a person, by doing anything which he intends or knows to be likely to cause death, commits culpable homicide by causing the death of any person, whose death he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause, the culpable homicide committed by the offender is of the description of which it would have been if he had caused the death of the person whose death he intended or knew himself to be likely to cause.
sections.simple: Known as 'transferred malice,' this states that if you intend to kill one person but accidentally kill another, you are still guilty of the crime as if you had killed the intended person.

sections.text: (1) Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. (2) When a group of five or more persons acting in concert commits murder on the ground of race, caste or community, sex, place of birth, language, personal belief or any other similar ground each member of such group shall be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Sets the punishment for murder as death or life imprisonment. Sub-section 2 specifically introduces the punishment for mob lynching or group-based murder.

sections.text: Whoever, being under sentence of imprisonment for life, commits murder, shall be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, which shall mean the remainder of that person's natural life.
sections.simple: Prescribes death or natural-life imprisonment for someone who commits murder while already serving a life sentence.

sections.text: Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment... not less than five years but which may extend to ten years... or with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years and with fine [if done with knowledge but without intent].
sections.simple: Provides different levels of punishment for culpable homicide that is not murder, depending on whether there was specific intent or just knowledge of the risk.

sections.text: (1) Whoever causes death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to five years... [2 years for medical practitioners]. (2) Whoever causes death... by rash and negligent driving... and escapes without reporting it to a police officer or a Magistrate soon after the incident, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years.
sections.simple: Punishes accidental deaths caused by negligence. It includes a specific provision for doctors and introduces a much higher 10-year penalty for 'hit-and-run' cases.

sections.text: If any child, any person of unsound mind, any delirious person or any person in a state of intoxication, commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Imposes severe penalties, up to the death penalty, for helping a child or mentally incapacitated person commit suicide.

sections.text: If any person commits suicide, whoever abets the commission of such suicide, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes the abetment (encouragement or assistance) of suicide with up to 10 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge... that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years... (2) [If the offender is a life-convict and hurt is caused, the penalty can be death].
sections.simple: Punishes attempted murder with up to 10 years in prison, or life/death if injury is caused by a life-convict.

sections.text: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge... that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years... [up to 7 years if hurt is caused].
sections.simple: Punishes attempts to commit culpable homicide (which is less severe than attempted murder).

sections.text: (1) Any continuing unlawful activity... by any person or a group... either as a member of an organised crime syndicate or on behalf of such syndicate... shall constitute organised crime. [Punishment: death or life imprisonment if death results; 5 years to life otherwise].
sections.simple: A new section defining 'Organised Crime' (like kidnapping, robbery, trafficking, or economic offences) and providing heavy penalties including death.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, being a member of a group or gang, either singly or jointly, commits any act of theft, snatching, cheating, unauthorised selling of tickets... is said to commit petty organised crime. [Punishment: 1 to 7 years].
sections.simple: A new section targeting common group crimes like snatching, pickpocketing, or ticket scamming.

sections.text: (1) Whoever does any act with the intent to threaten or likely to threaten the unity, integrity, sovereignty, security, or economic security of India... commits a terrorist act. [Punishment: death or life imprisonment if death results; 5 years to life otherwise].
sections.simple: A comprehensive new section defining and punishing terrorism, including economic terrorism and use of hazardous substances.

sections.text: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.
sections.simple: Defines basic 'hurt' as causing pain, sickness, or weakness.

sections.text: (1) Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person... is said 'voluntarily to cause hurt'. [Punishment: up to 1 year and/or 10,000 rupee fine].
sections.simple: Punishes intentionally causing simple bodily pain.

sections.text: The following kinds of hurt only are designated as 'grievous', namely:— (a) Emasculation; (b) [loss of sight]; (c) [loss of hearing]; (d) [loss of limb/joint]; (e) [permanent impairment]; (f) [disfiguration of head/face]; (g) [fracture/dislocation]; (h) [pain for 15 days].
sections.simple: Lists 8 specific types of severe injuries categorized as 'grievous hurt'.

sections.text: (1) Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt... is grievous hurt... is said 'voluntarily to cause grievous hurt'. [Punishment: up to 7 years]. (3) [If resulting in permanent disability or vegetative state: 10 years to life]. (4) [Group-based grievous hurt: up to 7 years].
sections.simple: Punishes causing severe injuries. It introduces life imprisonment for injuries leading to vegetative states and handles mob-based injuries.

sections.text: (1) [Hurt caused by dangerous weapons]: up to 3 years. (2) [Grievous hurt caused by dangerous weapons]: life imprisonment or 1 to 10 years.
sections.simple: Increases penalties for causing hurt or serious injury when using weapons like knives, guns, fire, or poison.

sections.text: (1) [Hurt to extort property]: up to 10 years. (2) [Grievous hurt to extort property]: life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
sections.simple: Punishes injuring someone to force them to give up property or money.

sections.text: (1) [Hurt to extort confession/restore property]: up to 7 years. (2) [Grievous hurt for same purpose]: up to 10 years.
sections.simple: Punishes injuring someone to force a confession or to get stolen property back.

sections.text: (1) [Hurt to deter public servant]: up to 5 years. (2) [Grievous hurt to deter public servant]: 1 to 10 years.
sections.simple: Protects public servants by punishing those who injure them to stop them from doing their job.

sections.text: (1) [Hurt on provocation]: up to 1 month. (2) [Grievous hurt on provocation]: up to 5 years.
sections.simple: Reduces the punishment if the injury was caused by a sudden and grave provocation.

sections.text: Whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person any poison... with intent to cause hurt... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Punishes the act of drugging or poisoning someone with intent to hurt or commit a crime.

sections.text: (1) [Acid attack causing permanent injury/vegetative state]: 10 years to life. (2) [Attempt to throw acid]: 5 to 7 years.
sections.simple: Specific section for acid attacks, providing a minimum of 10 years for actual attacks and up to 7 years for attempts.

sections.text: Whoever does any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life... [Punishment: 3 months to 3 years depending on if hurt/grievous hurt is caused].
sections.simple: Punishes reckless behavior that endangers others, even if no death occurs.

sections.text: (1) Whoever voluntarily obstructs any person so as to prevent that person from proceeding in any direction in which that person has a right to proceed, is said wrongfully to restrain that person. [Punishment: up to 1 month].
sections.simple: Defines and punishes blocking someone's path in one specific direction.

sections.text: (1) Whoever wrongfully restrains any person in such a manner as to prevent that person from proceedings beyond certain circumscribing limits, is said 'wrongfully to confine' that person. [Punishment ranges from 1 to 5 years depending on duration].
sections.simple: Defines and punishes trapping someone in a limited space (like a room) so they cannot leave.

sections.text: A person is said to use force to another if he causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that other...
sections.simple: Provides the technical definition of physical force used against another person.

sections.text: Whoever intentionally uses force to any person, without that person's consent, in order to the committing of any offence... is said to use criminal force to that other.
sections.simple: Defines 'criminal force' as using physical force to commit a crime or cause fear/injury.

sections.text: Whoever makes any gesture, or any preparation intending... to cause any person present to apprehend that he... is about to use criminal force... is said to commit an assault.
sections.simple: Defines assault as a gesture or action that makes someone believe they are about to be hit or touched with criminal force (words alone are not enough).

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three months...
sections.simple: General punishment for simple assault or use of criminal force.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years...
sections.simple: Punishes assaulting or using force against a public servant on duty.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to dishonour that person... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years...
sections.simple: Punishes using force to humiliate or dishonor someone.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting to commit theft on any property which that person is then wearing or carrying...
sections.simple: Punishes using force while trying to steal something from a person's body.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting wrongfully to confine that person...
sections.simple: Punishes using force while trying to trap or confine someone.

sections.text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person on grave and sudden provocation... [Punishment: up to 1 month].
sections.simple: Reduced penalty for assault if provoked.

sections.text: (1) Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship... [Punishment: up to 7 years].
sections.simple: Defines kidnapping as taking someone out of India or taking a minor/insane person away from their guardian.

sections.text: Whoever by force compels, or by any deceitful means induces, any person to go from any place, is said to abduct that person.
sections.simple: Defines abduction as forcing or tricking someone into moving from one place to another.

sections.text: (1) [Kidnapping for begging]: 10 years to life. (2) [Maiming a child for begging]: 20 years to life.
sections.simple: Imposes extreme penalties for kidnapping children to use them for begging, especially if they are mutilated.

sections.text: (1) [Kidnapping for murder]: life imprisonment or 10 years. (2) [Kidnapping for ransom]: death or life imprisonment.
sections.simple: Prescribes heavy penalties for kidnapping with intent to kill or for demanding ransom (the latter can carry the death penalty).

sections.text: Whoever imports into India from any country outside India any girl under the age of twenty-one years or any boy under the age of eighteen years with intent that girl or boy may be... forced or seduced to illicit intercourse...
sections.simple: Punishes the cross-border trafficking of minors for sexual exploitation with up to 10 years.

sections.text: Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines such person...
sections.simple: Punishes hiding a kidnapped person as if you kidnapped them yourself.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, for the purpose of exploitation recruits, transports, harbours... by using threats... force... fraud... commits the offence of trafficking. [Punishment ranges from 7 years to natural life].
sections.simple: Defines human trafficking and provides various punishments based on the number of victims, age of victims, and involvement of public servants.

sections.text: (1) [Engaging trafficked child for sexual exploitation]: 5 to 10 years. (2) [Engaging trafficked adult for same]: 3 to 7 years.
sections.simple: Punishes those who use trafficked persons for sexual acts, with higher penalties if the victim is a child.

sections.text: Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or deals in slaves, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or... not exceeding ten years...
sections.simple: Punishes habitual dealing in slaves.

sections.text: Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to one year...
sections.simple: Punishes forcing someone to work against their will (forced labor).

title: BNS: Chapter VII. Of Offences Against the State
category: Crimes involving waging war against the government, endangering national sovereignty, and relations with foreign states

sections.text: Whoever wages war against the Government of India, or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: The ultimate 'do not do'—waging war against the country or even helping someone else do it is punishable by life in prison or the death penalty.

sections.text: Whoever within or without India conspires to commit any of the offences punishable by section 147, or conspires to overawe, by means of criminal force or the show of criminal force, the Central Government or any State Government, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Planning to wage war or using force to intimidate the government is a crime, even if you are just talking about it or planning it from outside India.

sections.text: Whoever collects men, arms or ammunition or otherwise prepares to wage war with the intention of either waging or being prepared to wage war against the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment for life or imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Gathering a private army or stockpiling weapons with the intent to fight the government gets you up to 10 years or life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, by any act, or by any illegal omission, conceals the existence of a design to wage war against the Government of India, intending by such concealment to facilitate, or knowing it to be likely that such concealment will facilitate, the waging of such war, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If you know someone is planning to wage war against the country and you hide that information to help them, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.

sections.text: Whoever, with the intention of inducing or compelling the President of India, or the Governor of any State, to exercise or refrain from exercising in any manner any of the lawful powers of such President or Governor, assaults or wrongfully restrains, or attempts wrongfully to restrain, or overawes, by means of criminal force or the show of criminal force, or attempts so to overawe, such President or Governor, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Assaulting or using force to intimidate the President or a Governor to make them do (or stop doing) their job is punishable by up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, purposely or knowingly, by words, either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representation, or by electronic communication or by use of financial means, or otherwise, excites or attempts to excite, secession or armed rebellion or subversive activities, or encourages feelings of separatist activities or endangers sovereignty or unity and integrity of India; or indulges in or commits any such act shall be punished with imprisonment for life or with imprisonment which may extend to seven years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: This replaces the old sedition law. It punishes anyone who uses words, digital media, or money to incite rebellion, separatism, or activities that threaten the unity and sovereignty of India. The penalty ranges from 7 years to life.

sections.text: Whoever wages war against the Government of any foreign State at peace with the Government of India or attempts to wage such war, or abets the waging of such war, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, to which fine may be added, or with fine.
sections.simple: You can't use India as a base to wage war against friendly foreign countries. Doing so carries up to a 7-year sentence or life.

sections.text: Whoever commits depredation, or makes preparations to commit depredation, on the territories of any foreign State at peace with the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of any property used or intended to be used in committing such depredation, or acquired by such depredation.
sections.simple: Raiding or looting the territory of a friendly foreign nation is a crime punishable by 7 years in prison and the loss of any property you stole or used in the raid.

sections.text: Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 153 and 154, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of the property so received.
sections.simple: If you take or buy property that you know was looted from a friendly foreign state during a war or raid, you face up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape from any place in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If a government official in charge of a State prisoner or prisoner of war lets them go on purpose, they face 10 years to life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape from any place of confinement in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If a government official is careless and a State prisoner escapes because of that negligence, the official can be jailed for up to 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever knowingly aids or assists any State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or harbours or conceals any such prisoner who has escaped from lawful custody, or offers or attempts to offer any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Helping a State prisoner escape, hiding them afterward, or trying to stop the police from catching them again is a major crime punishable by up to 10 years or life.

title: BNS: Chapter VIII. Of Offences Relating to the Army, Navy and Air Force
category: Crimes involving the encouragement of mutiny, desertion, and insubordination within the armed forces

sections.text: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India or attempts to seduce any such officer, soldier, sailor or airman from his allegiance or his duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Helping or encouraging a member of the armed forces to mutiny (rebel against authority), or trying to trick them into abandoning their duty, is a major crime punishable by 10 years to life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall, if mutiny be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If you encourage a mutiny and it actually happens, you face the most severe penalties, including the death penalty or life imprisonment.

sections.text: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Encouraging a member of the military to attack their superior officer while that officer is on duty is punishable by up to 3 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall, if such assault be committed in consequence of that abetment be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If you encourage an attack on a superior officer and the attack actually takes place, your punishment increases to up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Helping or encouraging a member of the armed forces to desert (run away from) their service is punishable by up to 2 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, except as hereinafter excepted, knowing or having reason to believe that an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, has deserted, harbours such officer, soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine or with both. Exception.—This provision does not extend to the case in which the harbour is given by the spouse of the deserter.
sections.simple: Hiding or protecting a military deserter is a crime carrying a 2-year sentence. However, a husband or wife cannot be punished for hiding their deserting spouse.

sections.text: The master or person in charge of a merchant vessel, on board of which any deserter from the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India is concealed, shall, though ignorant of such concealment, be liable to a penalty not exceeding three thousand rupees, if he might have known of such concealment but for some neglect of his duty as such master or person in charge, or but for some want of discipline on board of the vessel.
sections.simple: If a deserter hides on a commercial ship, the captain can be fined up to 3,000 rupees if the hiding was possible because the captain was negligent or failed to keep order on the ship.

sections.text: Whoever abets what he knows to be an act of insubordination by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force, of the Government of India, shall, if such act of insubordination be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Encouraging a soldier to disobey orders is a crime. If they actually disobey because of your encouragement, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.

sections.text: No person subject to the Air Force Act, 1950, the Army Act, 1950 and the Navy Act, 1957, or shall be subject to punishment under this Sanhita for any of the offences defined in this Chapter.
sections.simple: Actual members of the armed forces are not punished under these specific sections of the BNS; they are instead judged by their own military laws (Courts-Martial).
