sections.text: Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Army, Naval or Air service of the Government of India, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by such a soldier, sailor or airman with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: It is a crime to dress up in a military uniform or carry military badges to trick people into thinking you are a soldier. The penalty is up to 3 months in jail.

title: BNS: Chapter IX. Of Offences Relating to Elections
category: Offences involving bribery, undue influence, personation, and false statements during elections

sections.text: For the purposes of this Chapter— (a) "candidate" means a person who has been nominated as a candidate at any election; (b) "electoral right" means the right of a person to stand, or not to stand as, or to withdraw from being, a candidate or to vote or refrain from voting at an election.
sections.simple: Defines 'candidate' as anyone nominated for an election and 'electoral right' as the legal right to run for office, withdraw your candidacy, or cast a vote.

sections.text: (1) Whoever— (i) gives a gratification to any person with the object of inducing him or any other person to exercise any electoral right or of rewarding any person for having exercised any such right; or (ii) accepts either for himself or for any other person any gratification as a reward for exercising any such right or for inducing or attempting to induce any other person to exercise any such right, commits the offence of bribery: Provided that a declaration of public policy or a promise of public action shall not be an offence under this section. (2) A person who offers, or agrees to give, or offers or attempts to procure, a gratification shall be deemed to give a gratification. (3) A person who obtains or agrees to accept or attempts to obtain a gratification shall be deemed to accept a gratification, and a person who accepts a gratification as a motive for doing what he does not intend to do, or as a reward for doing what he has not done, shall be deemed to have accepted the gratification as a reward.
sections.simple: Bribery in an election involves giving or receiving rewards to influence how someone uses their right to vote or be a candidate. Official public policy promises are not considered bribes.

sections.text: (1) Whoever voluntarily interferes or attempts to interfere with the free exercise of any electoral right commits the offence of undue influence at an election. (2) Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section (1), whoever— (a) threatens any candidate or voter, or any person in whom a candidate or voter is interested, with injury of any kind; or (b) induces or attempts to induce a candidate or voter to believe that he or any person in whom he is interested will become or will be rendered an object of Divine displeasure or of spiritual censure, shall be deemed to interfere with the free exercise of the electoral right of such candidate or voter, within the meaning of sub-section (1). (3) A declaration of public policy or a promise of public action or the mere exercise of a legal right without intent to interfere with an electoral right, shall not be deemed to be interference within the meaning of this section.
sections.simple: It is a crime to interfere with someone's free choice in an election through threats of injury or by claiming they will face 'divine displeasure' or spiritual punishment for their choice.

sections.text: Whoever at an election applies for a voting paper or votes in the name of any other person, whether living or dead, or in a fictitious name, or who having voted once at such election applies at the same election for a voting paper in his own name, and whoever abets, procures or attempts to procure the voting by any person in any such way, commits the offence of personation at an election: Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a person who has been authorised to vote as proxy for an elector under any law for the time being in force in so far as he votes as a proxy for such elector.
sections.simple: Personation is the crime of voting in someone else's name (whether they are alive, dead, or made up) or trying to vote more than once in the same election. Authorized proxy voting is a legal exception.

sections.text: Whoever commits the offence of bribery shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both: Provided that bribery by treating shall be punished with fine only. Explanation.—"Treating" means that form of bribery where the gratification consists in food, drink, entertainment, or provision.
sections.simple: Election bribery is generally punished with up to a year in jail or a fine. If the bribe is simply providing food, drinks, or entertainment ('treating'), the punishment is only a fine.

sections.text: Whoever commits the offence of undue influence or personation at an election shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Using illegal influence or faking your identity to vote is punishable by up to one year in prison, a fine, or both.

sections.text: Whoever with intent to affect the result of an election makes or publishes any statement purporting to be a statement of fact which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, in relation to the personal character or conduct of any candidate shall be punished with fine.
sections.simple: Lying about a candidate's personal character or conduct to change the election outcome is a crime punishable by a fine.

sections.text: Whoever without the general or special authority in writing of a candidate incurs or authorises expenses on account of the holding of any public meeting, or upon any advertisement, circular or publication, or in any other way whatsoever for the purpose of promoting or procuring the election of such candidate, shall be punished with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees: Provided that if any person having incurred any such expenses not exceeding the amount of ten rupees without authority obtains within ten days from the date on which such expenses were incurred the approval in writing of the candidate, he shall be deemed to have incurred such expenses with the authority of the candidate.
sections.simple: Spending money on a candidate's campaign (like for ads or meetings) without their written permission is illegal and punishable by a fine of up to 10,000 rupees. Very small costs (under 10 rupees) can be approved after the fact.

sections.text: Whoever being required by any law for the time being in force or any rule having the force of law to keep accounts of expenses incurred at or in connection with an election fails to keep such accounts shall be punished with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
sections.simple: If you are legally required to keep records of election spending and fail to do so, you can be fined up to 5,000 rupees.

title: BNS: Chapter X. Of Offences Relating to Coin, Currency-Notes, Bank-Notes, and Government Stamps
category: Crimes involving the forgery, counterfeiting, and illegal possession of money and government revenue or postage stamps

sections.text: Whoever counterfeits, or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting, any coin, stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Making fake money, coins, or government revenue stamps, or even performing just one part of the manufacturing process, is a serious crime punishable by life imprisonment or up to 10 years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever imports or exports, or sells or delivers to, or buys or receives from, any other person, or otherwise traffics or uses as genuine, any forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be forged or counterfeit, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: It is a major crime to trade, buy, sell, import, export, or attempt to spend fake money or government stamps if you know they are forgeries.

sections.text: Whoever has in his possession any forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be forged or counterfeit and intending to use the same as genuine or that it may be used as genuine, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both. Explanation.—If a person establishes the possession of the forged or counterfeit coin, stamp, currency-note or bank-note to be from a lawful source, it shall not constitute an offence under this section.
sections.simple: Possessing fake money or stamps with the intent to use them is punishable by up to 7 years in jail. You are not guilty if you can prove you obtained them from a legitimate source without knowing they were fake.

sections.text: Whoever makes or mends, or performs any part of the process of making or mending, or buys or sells or disposes of, or has in his possession, any machinery, die, or instrument or material for the purpose of being used, or knowing or having reason to believe that it is intended to be used, for forging or counterfeiting any coin, stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, currency-note or bank-note, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Owning, making, or selling tools, machinery, or materials intended for forging money or government stamps carries heavy penalties, including life imprisonment.

sections.text: (1) Whoever makes, or causes to be made, or uses for any purpose whatsoever, or delivers to any person, any document purporting to be, or in any way resembling, or so nearly resembling as to be calculated to deceive, any currency-note or bank-note shall be punished with fine which may extend to three hundred rupees. (2) If any person, whose name appears on a document the making of which is an offence under sub-section (1), refuses, without lawful excuse, to disclose to a police officer on being so required the name and address of the person by whom it was printed or otherwise made, he shall be punished with fine which may extend to six hundred rupees. (3) Where the name of any person appears on any document in respect of which any person is charged with an offence under sub-section (1) or on any other document used or distributed in connection with that document it may, until the contrary is proved, be presumed that the person caused the document to be made.
sections.simple: It is illegal to create documents that look like real currency to deceive people. While the fine is small, refusing to identify the printer to the police results in a higher fine. The law presumes the person named on the document made it.

sections.text: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to the Government, removes or effaces from any substance, bearing any stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, any writing or document for which such stamp has been used, or removes from any writing or document a stamp which has been used for such writing or document, in order that such stamp may be used for a different writing or document, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Washing off old writing from a used government revenue stamp or removing it from an old document to reuse it is a crime punishable by up to 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to the Government, uses for any purpose a stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, which he knows to have been before used, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Knowingly using a government revenue stamp that has already been used is punishable by up to 2 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, fraudulently or with intent to cause loss to Government, erases or removes from a stamp issued by Government for the purpose of revenue, any mark, put or impressed upon such stamp for the purpose of denoting that the same has been used, or knowingly has in his possession or sells or disposes of any such stamp from which such mark has been erased or removed, or sells or disposes of any such stamp which he knows to have been used, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Removing the 'used' mark from a revenue stamp, or possessing and selling stamps that have been tampered with in this way, can lead to 3 years in jail.

sections.text: (1) Whoever— (a) makes, knowingly utters, deals in or sells any fictitious stamp, or knowingly uses for any postal purpose any fictitious stamp; or (b) has in his possession, without lawful excuse, any fictitious stamp; or (c) makes or, without lawful excuse, has in his possession any die, plate, instrument or materials for making any fictitious stamp, shall be punished with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees. (2) Any such stamp, die, plate, instrument or materials in the possession of any person for making any fictitious stamp may be seized and, if seized shall be forfeited. (3) In this section "fictitious stamp" means any stamp falsely purporting to be issued by Government for the purpose of denoting a rate of postage, or any facsimile or imitation or representation, whether on paper or otherwise, of any stamp issued by Government for that purpose.
sections.simple: Making, using, or selling fake postage stamps (stamps for mail) is illegal and punishable by a fine. The fake stamps and tools to make them will be confiscated by the state.

sections.text: Whoever, being employed in any mint lawfully established in India, does any act, or omits what he is legally bound to do, with the intention of causing any coin issued from that mint to be of a different weight or composition from the weight or composition fixed by law, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If an employee at a government mint purposely makes coins that are the wrong weight or composed of the wrong materials, they face up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, without lawful authority, takes out of any mint, lawfully established in India, any coining tool or instrument, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Stealing tools or instruments used to make coins from a government mint is a crime punishable by up to 7 years.

title: BNS: Chapter XI. Of Offences Against the Public Tranquillity
category: Offences involving unlawful assembly, rioting, and acts that disturb public peace and harmony

sections.text: (1) An assembly of five or more persons is designated an "unlawful assembly", if the common object of the persons composing that assembly is— (a) to overawe by criminal force, or show of criminal force, the Central Government or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State, or any public servant in the exercise of the lawful power of such public servant; or (b) to resist the execution of any law, or of any legal process; or (c) to commit any mischief or criminal trespass, or other offence; or (d) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to any person, to take or obtain possession of any property, or to deprive any person of the enjoyment of a right of way, or of the use of water or other incorporeal right of which he is in possession or enjoyment, or to enforce any right or supposed right; or (e) by means of criminal force, or show of criminal force, to compel any person to do what he is not legally bound to do, or to omit to do what he is legally entitled to do. (2) Whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly.
sections.simple: An unlawful assembly is a group of five or more people whose shared goal is to intimidate the government, break the law, commit a crime, seize property by force, or force someone to do something against their will. Simply joining such a group while knowing its illegal purpose makes you a member.

sections.text: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed in prosecution of that object, every person who, at the time of the committing of that offence, is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.
sections.simple: If one person in an unlawful assembly commits a crime to achieve the group's goal, every single member of that group is held legally responsible for that crime, even if they didn't personally commit the act.

sections.text: (1) Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both. (2) Whoever joins or continues in an unlawful assembly, knowing that such unlawful assembly has been commanded in the manner prescribed by law to disperse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. (3) Whoever is a member of an unlawful assembly, shall, if he is armed with any deadly weapon, or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Basic membership in an unlawful assembly can lead to 6 months in jail. If you stay after being ordered by authorities to leave, or if you show up with a deadly weapon, the punishment increases to up to 2 years.

sections.text: Whoever, being a member of an unlawful assembly, is guilty of rioting, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If an unlawful assembly starts using actual force or violence, it becomes 'rioting,' and members can be jailed for up to 2 years.

sections.text: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with a deadly weapon or with anything which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If you participate in a riot while carrying a deadly weapon, you face a harsher penalty of up to 3 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, by force, threat, or any other means, obstructs or attempts to obstruct any officer or other person in the exercise of his duty to disperse an unlawful assembly or to suppress a riot or affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Trying to stop the police or authorities from breaking up an unlawful assembly or a riot is a crime punishable by up to 3 years in jail.

sections.text: When two or more persons, by fighting in a public place, disturb the public peace, they are said to 'commit an affray'. Whoever commits an affray shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: An 'affray' is a public fight between two or more people that disturbs the peace. It is punishable by up to one month in jail or a 5,000 rupee fine.

sections.text: (1) Whoever— (a) by words, either spoken or written, or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic communication or otherwise, promotes or attempts to promote, on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, caste or community or any other ground whatsoever, disharmony or feelings of enmity, hatred or ill-will between different religious, racial, language or regional groups or castes or communities; or (b) commits any act which is prejudicial to the maintenance of harmony... shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. (2) [Punishment increases to 5 years if the act is committed in a place of worship].
sections.simple: This section punishes hate speech and acts that stir up hatred or enmity between different religious, racial, or regional groups. The punishment is up to 3 years, increasing to 5 years if done in a place of worship.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, by words either spoken or written, or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic communication or otherwise,— (a) makes or publishes any imputation that any class of persons cannot, by reason of their being members of any religious, racial, language or regional group or caste or community, bear true allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established or uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India; or (b) [claims that groups should be denied their rights as citizens]... shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: It is a crime to make public claims that certain groups (based on religion, race, etc.) are unpatriotic, cannot follow the Constitution, or should be denied their rights as citizens. This is considered a threat to national integration.

title: BNS: Chapter XII. Of Offences By or Relating to Public Servants
category: Crimes committed by public servants through illegal conduct and the misuse of authority, and crimes involving the personation of officials.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law as to the way in which he is to conduct himself as such public servant, intending to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will by such disobedience, cause injury to any person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If a government official intentionally ignores the law regarding how they should do their job in order to harm someone, they can be jailed for up to a year or fined.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant,- (a) knowingly disobeys any direction of the law which prohibits him from requiring the attendance at any place of any person for the purpose of investigation into an offence or any other matter, or (b) knowingly disobeys, to the prejudice of any person, any other direction of the law regulating the manner in which he shall conduct such investigation; or (c) fails to record any information given to him under sub-section (1) of section 173 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 in relation to cognizable offence punishable under section 64, section 65, section 66, section 67, section 68, section 70, section 71, section 74, section 76, section 77, section 79, section 124, section 143 or section 144, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: This section punishes public servants who break specific rules during investigations, such as forcing someone to appear illegally or refusing to file reports for serious crimes like sexual assault. The punishment is between six months and two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being in charge of a hospital, public or private, whether run by the Central Government, the State Government, local bodies or any other person, contravenes the provisions of section 397 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: A person in charge of any hospital (government or private) who refuses to provide required treatment to a victim can be sentenced to up to one year in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, and being, as such public servant, charged with the preparation or translation of any document or electronic record, frames, prepares or translates that document or electronic record in a manner which he knows or believes to be incorrect, intending thereby to cause or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If a public servant tasked with creating or translating a document purposely makes it incorrect to hurt someone, they face up to three years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound as such public servant not to engage in trade, engages in trade, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both or with community service.
sections.simple: A public servant who is legally forbidden from doing business but does it anyway can be jailed for up to a year or assigned community service.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, and being legally bound as such public servant, not to purchase or bid for certain property, purchases or bids for that property, either in his own name or in the name of another, or jointly, or in shares with others, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both; and the property, if purchased, shall be confiscated.
sections.simple: A public servant who is legally banned from buying or bidding on certain properties (like those they are selling officially) but does so anyway faces up to two years in jail and loses the property.

sections.text: Whoever pretends to hold any particular office as a public servant, knowing that he does not hold such office or falsely personates any other person holding such office, and in such assumed character does or attempts to do any act under colour of such office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than six months but which may extend to three years and with fine.
sections.simple: Pretending to be a public official (like a policeman or tax officer) and trying to perform official acts in that false identity is a crime punishable by six months to three years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, not belonging to a certain class of public servants, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by that class of public servants, with the intention that it may be believed, or with the knowledge that it is likely to be believed, that he belongs to that class of public servants, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Wearing a uniform or carrying symbols (like a badge) of a public official to trick people into thinking you are one is illegal and can lead to a three-month prison sentence or a fine.

title: BNS: Chapter XIII. Of Contempts of the Lawful Authority of Public Servants
category: Offences involving the disobedience of legal orders, summons, and the obstruction of public servants in their official duties.

sections.text: Whoever absconds in order to avoid being served with a summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue such summons, notice or order,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where such summons or notice or order is to attend in person or by agent, or to produce a document or an electronic record in a Court shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Hiding or running away to avoid receiving a legal notice or summons from a public official is a crime. The penalty is more severe (up to six months) if the notice was specifically for a court appearance or to provide evidence.

sections.text: Whoever in any manner intentionally prevents the serving on himself, or on any other person, of any summons, notice or order proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue such summons, notice or order, or intentionally prevents the lawful affixing to any place of any such summons, notice or order or intentionally removes any such summons, notice or order from any place to which it is lawfully affixed or intentionally prevents the lawful making of any proclamation, under the authority of any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to direct such proclamation to be made,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the summons, notice, order or proclamation is to attend in person or by agent, or to produce a document or electronic record in a Court, with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Intentionally stopping a legal notice from being delivered, tearing down a legally posted notice, or preventing a public announcement is illegal. Penalties increase if the order involved a court matter.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound to attend in person or by an agent at a certain place and time in obedience to a summons, notice, order, or proclamation proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue the same, intentionally omits to attend at that place or time or departs from the place where he is bound to attend before the time at which it is lawful for him to depart,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the summons, notice, order or proclamation is to attend in person or by agent in a Court with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If you are legally required to show up at a specific time and place for an official reason and you intentionally don't go or leave early without permission, you can be jailed or fined.

sections.text: Whoever fails to appear at the specified place and the specified time as required by a proclamation published under sub-section (1) of section 84 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both, or with community service, and where a declaration has been made under sub-section (4) of that section pronouncing him as a proclaimed offender, he shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Failing to appear when you have been officially declared a 'proclaimed offender' is a major crime. You can face up to three years in prison generally, or up to seven years if the court has officially designated you as a fugitive.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound to produce or deliver up any document or electronic record to any public servant, as such, intentionally omits so to produce or deliver up the same,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) and where the document or electronic record is to be produced or delivered up to a Court with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If the law requires you to hand over a document or digital file to an official and you refuse to do so, you can be punished with jail time or a fine.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound to give any notice or to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, as such, intentionally omits to give such notice or to furnish such information in the manner and at the time required by law,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the notice or information required to be given respects the commission of an offence, or is required for the purpose of preventing the commission of an offence, or in order to the apprehension of an offender, with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both; (c) where the notice or information required to be given is required by an order passed under section 394 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Intentionally failing to provide information to the authorities when the law requires you to—especially information about a crime or to help catch a criminal—is punishable by up to six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, as such, furnishes, as true, information on the subject which he knows or has reason to believe to be false, (a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both; (b) where the information which he is legally bound to give respects the commission of an offence, or is required for the purpose of preventing the commission of an offence, or in order to the apprehension of an offender, with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Lying to a public official when you are legally required to tell the truth is a crime. If the lie is about a crime, the penalty can be up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever refuses to bind himself by an oath or affirmation to state the truth, when required so to bind himself by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall so bind himself, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If an official has the legal right to make you swear or promise to tell the truth and you refuse to take that oath, you can be jailed for up to six months.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound to state the truth on any subject to any public servant, refuses to answer any question demanded of him touching that subject by such public servant in the exercise of the legal powers of such public servant, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Refusing to answer questions from a public official who has the legal authority to ask them is punishable by a six-month jail sentence or a fine.

sections.text: Whoever refuses to sign any statement made by him, when required to sign that statement by a public servant legally competent to require that he shall sign that statement, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to three thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If you give a statement to a public official and then refuse to sign it when legally required to do so, you can be jailed for three months.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or affirmation to state the truth on any subject to any public servant or other person authorised by law to administer such oath or affirmation, makes, to such public servant or other person as aforesaid, touching that subject, any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Lying under oath to a public official or authorized person is a serious offence carrying a punishment of up to three years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever gives to any public servant any information which he knows or believes to be false, intending thereby to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, such public servant- (a) to do or omit anything which such public servant ought not to do or omit if the true state of facts respecting which such information is given were known by him; or (b) to use the lawful power of such public servant to the injury or annoyance of any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Giving false information to a public official to trick them into using their power to hurt or annoy someone else is punishable by up to a year in prison.

sections.text: Whoever offers any resistance to the taking of any property by the lawful authority of any public servant, knowing or having reason to believe that he is such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Resisting a public official who is legally authorized to seize or take property is a crime punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever intentionally obstructs any sale of property offered for sale by the lawful authority of any public servant, as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Trying to stop or block a legal public auction or sale conducted by the government is punishable by one month in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, at any sale of property held by the lawful authority of a public servant, as such, purchases or bids for any property on account of any person, whether himself or any other, whom he knows to be under a legal incapacity to purchase that property at that sale, or bids for such property not intending to perform the obligations under which he lays himself by such bidding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: It is illegal to make fake bids at a government sale or to buy property on behalf of someone who is legally banned from doing so.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any public servant in the discharge of his public functions, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand and five hundred rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Intentionally getting in the way of a public official while they are doing their job is punishable by up to three months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, being bound by law to render or furnish assistance to any public servant in the execution of his public duty, intentionally omits to give such assistance,-(a) shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to two thousand and five hundred rupees, or with both; (b) and where such assistance be demanded of him by a public servant legally competent to make such demand for the purposes of executing any process lawfully issued by a Court or of preventing the commission of an offence, or suppressing a riot, or affray, or of apprehending a person charged with or guilty of an offence, or of having escaped from lawful custody, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If the law says you must help an official (like helping a policeman stop a riot or catch a criminal) and you refuse to do so, you can be jailed for up to six months.

sections.text: Whoever, knowing that, by an order promulgated by a public servant lawfully empowered to promulgate such order, he is directed to abstain from a certain act, or to take certain order with certain property in his possession or under his management, disobeys such direction,-(a) shall, if such disobedience causes or tends to cause obstruction, annoyance or injury, or risk of obstruction, annoyance or injury, to any person lawfully employed, be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to two thousand and five hundred rupees, or with both; (b) and where such disobedience causes or tends to cause danger to human life, health or safety, or causes or tends to cause a riot or affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Breaking an official public order (like an order to stop a noisy protest or stay out of a restricted area) is a crime. If the disobedience creates a danger to life or causes a riot, the punishment increases to one year in prison.

sections.text: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to any public servant, or to any person in whom he believes that public servant to be interested, for the purpose of inducing that public servant to do any act, or to forbear or delay to do any act, connected with the exercise of the public functions of such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Threatening a public official (or their family) to make them do something they shouldn't, or to stop them from doing their duty, is punishable by up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever holds out any threat of injury to any person for the purpose of inducing that person to refrain or desist from making a legal application for protection against any injury to any public servant legally empowered as such to give such protection, or to cause such protection to be given, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Threatening someone to stop them from asking the government for protection or help is a crime punishable by up to one year in jail.

sections.text: Whoever attempts to commit suicide with the intent to compel or restrain any public servant from discharging his official duty shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both, or with community service.
sections.simple: Using a suicide attempt as a way to blackmail or pressure a public official into doing (or not doing) their job is a crime punishable by up to one year in prison or community service.

title: BNS: Chapter XIV. Of False Evidence and Offences Against Public Justice
category: Offences involving perjury, fabrication of evidence, screening of offenders, and resisting legal processes.

sections.text: Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
sections.simple: Committing perjury: If you are legally required to tell the truth (like under oath) and you lie, you are guilty of giving false evidence.

sections.text: Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry in any book or record, or electronic record or makes any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that such circumstance, false entry or false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding... is said 'to fabricate false evidence'.
sections.simple: Faking evidence: This involves creating false records or planting evidence to trick a court or official into making a wrong decision.

sections.text: (1) Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine... (2) [Other cases: up to three years].
sections.simple: General punishment for lying in court or faking evidence is up to seven years in prison. In non-court matters, the punishment is up to three years.

sections.text: (1) Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence, intending thereby to cause... any person to be convicted of an offence which is capital... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years... (2) If an innocent person be convicted and executed... [punishment is death or life imprisonment].
sections.simple: If you lie to get someone sentenced to death, you face life in prison. If your lie actually causes an innocent person to be executed, you can be sentenced to death yourself.

sections.text: Whoever gives or fabricates false evidence intending thereby to cause... any person to be convicted of an offence which... is not capital, but punishable with imprisonment for life, or... seven years or upwards, shall be punished as a person convicted of that offence would be liable to be punished.
sections.simple: If you lie to get someone convicted of a serious crime (punishable by 7+ years or life), you will receive the same punishment that the innocent person would have faced.

sections.text: (1) Whoever threatens another... with intent to cause that person to give false evidence shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years... (2) If [an] innocent person is convicted... [of a serious crime], the person who threatens shall be punished with the same punishment.
sections.simple: Blackmailing or threatening someone to force them to lie in court is punishable by up to seven years. If your threat leads to an innocent person being wrongly convicted of a major crime, you get their sentence.

sections.text: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use as true or genuine evidence any evidence which he knows to be false or fabricated, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave or fabricated false evidence.
sections.simple: Knowingly using fake evidence in court is punished exactly the same as if you had created the fake evidence yourself.

sections.text: Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law... knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
sections.simple: Signing or issuing a legally required certificate (like a medical or fitness certificate) knowing it contains lies is treated as perjury.

sections.text: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use any such certificate as a true certificate, knowing the same to be false... shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
sections.simple: Using a false certificate as if it were real carries the same penalty as lying under oath.

sections.text: Whoever, in any declaration made or subscribed by him, which declaration any Court or any public servant... is bound or authorised by law to receive as evidence... makes any statement which is false... shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
sections.simple: Making a false statement in a formal legal declaration is the same as lying in court.

sections.text: Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use as true any such declaration, knowing the same to be false... shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
sections.simple: Using a false legal declaration as if it were true is a crime equivalent to perjury.

sections.text: Whoever... causes any evidence of the commission of [an] offence to disappear, with the intention of screening the offender... or gives any information... which he knows or believes to be false [shall be punished with up to seven years, three years, or 1/4th of the offender's term depending on the crime].
sections.simple: Destroying evidence or lying to the police to protect a criminal from being caught is a crime. The heavier the criminal's crime, the heavier your punishment for helping them hide.

sections.text: Whoever... intentionally omits to give any information respecting that offence which he is legally bound to give, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine... or with both.
sections.simple: If you are legally required to report a crime and you intentionally stay silent, you can be jailed for six months.

sections.text: Whoever... gives any information respecting that offence which he knows or believes to be false, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Knowingly giving the police false information about a crime is punishable by up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever secretes or destroys any document or electronic record which he may be lawfully compelled to produce as evidence... with the intention of preventing the same from being produced... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine... or with both.
sections.simple: Hiding or destroying documents or digital records to keep them from being used as evidence in court is punishable by up to three years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever falsely personates another, and in such assumed character makes any admission or statement... or does any other act in any suit or criminal prosecution, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Pretending to be someone else during a legal case or court proceeding is a crime punishable by up to three years.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently removes, conceals, transfers or delivers to any person any property... intending thereby to prevent that property... from being taken as a forfeiture or in satisfaction of a fine... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine... or with both.
sections.simple: Hiding your property so the court can't seize it to pay a fine or as a penalty is punishable by up to three years.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently accepts, receives or claims any property... knowing that he has no right... intending thereby to prevent that property... from being taken as a forfeiture or in satisfaction of a fine... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Faking a claim to property just to stop the court from seizing it is illegal and carries up to a two-year sentence.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently causes or suffers a decree or order to be passed against him at the suit of any person for a sum not due... or for any property... to which such person is not entitled... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Purposely letting someone win a fake court case against you to hide your money or assets is punishable by two years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly... makes in a Court any claim which he knows to be false, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Making a completely false claim in court to trick the judge is punishable by up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently obtains a decree or order against any person for a sum not due... or for anything in respect of which it has been satisfied... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Tricking a court into giving you a judgment for money you aren't actually owed is a crime.

sections.text: Whoever, with intent to cause injury to any person, institutes... any criminal proceeding against that person, or falsely charges any person with having committed an offence, knowing that there is no just or lawful ground... [punishment up to five years, or ten years for serious charges].
sections.simple: Filing a false police report or court case against someone just to hurt them is a major crime. You face up to five years generally, or up to ten years if you falsely accused them of a very serious crime.

sections.text: Whenever an offence has been committed, whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows... to be the offender, with the intention of screening him from legal punishment... [punishment varies from 1/4th of the offender's term to five years]. Exception.—[Does not apply to spouses].
sections.simple: Hiding a criminal to help them escape justice is a crime. The penalty depends on how serious the criminal's original crime was. Husbands and wives are exempt from this specific rule.

sections.text: Whoever accepts... any gratification... in consideration of his concealing an offence or of his screening any person from legal punishment... [punishment varies based on the crime].
sections.simple: Taking a bribe to hide a crime or protect a criminal from the law is punishable by prison time.

sections.text: Whoever gives... any gratification... in consideration of that person's concealing an offence... [punishment varies]. Exception.—[Does not apply to compoundable offences].
sections.simple: Offering a bribe to someone so they will help you hide a crime or escape punishment is a crime.

sections.text: Whoever takes... any gratification under pretence... of helping any person to recover any movable property of which he shall have been deprived by any offence... shall, unless he uses all means... to cause the offender to be apprehended... be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years.
sections.simple: Taking money to help someone get their stolen stuff back is illegal unless you also do everything you can to help the police catch the thief.

sections.text: Whoever... harbours or conceals [a person who escaped from custody or whose arrest was ordered]... with the intention of preventing him from being apprehended... [punishment from 1/4th of the term to seven years]. Exception.—[Does not apply to spouses].
sections.simple: Hiding a fugitive or someone who escaped from jail to keep them from being caught is a crime. This does not apply if you are hiding your spouse.

sections.text: Whoever, knowing... that any persons are about to commit or have recently committed robbery or dacoity, harbours them... shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine. Exception.—[Does not apply to spouses].
sections.simple: Hiding members of a gang of robbers or dacoits is a serious crime carrying up to seven years of hard labor.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, knowingly disobeys any direction of the law... intending thereby to save... any person from legal punishment... or with intent to save... any property from forfeiture... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If an official breaks the law specifically to protect someone from being punished or to save their property from being seized, the official can be jailed for two years.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant... frames [a] record or writing in a manner which he knows to be incorrect, with intent to cause... loss or injury... or with intent thereby to save... any person from legal punishment... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If an official purposely writes a fake or incorrect report to help a criminal or hurt the public, they face up to three years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, corruptly or maliciously makes or pronounces in any stage of a judicial proceeding, any report, order, verdict, or decision which he knows to be contrary to law, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: A judge or official who gives a court ruling or report they *know* is illegal and wrong can be jailed for seven years.

sections.text: Whoever, being in any office which gives him legal authority to commit persons for trial or to confinement... corruptly or maliciously commits any person... knowing that in so doing he is acting contrary to law, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If an official uses their power to send someone to jail or trial while knowing that doing so is illegal, they face seven years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, legally bound... to apprehend... any person charged with... an offence, intentionally omits to apprehend such person, or intentionally suffers such person to escape... [punishment from two to seven years depending on the crime].
sections.simple: If a policeman or official intentionally lets a criminal go or refuses to arrest them, they are punished based on the seriousness of the criminal's offence.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant, legally bound... to apprehend... any person under sentence of a Court... intentionally omits to apprehend... or intentionally suffers such person to escape... [punishment from three years to life depending on the sentence].
sections.simple: If an official intentionally lets a convicted prisoner escape, they can be jailed for three years, seven years, or even life, depending on the prisoner's original sentence.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant legally bound... to keep in confinement any person... negligently suffers such person to escape from confinement, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If an official is simply careless and a prisoner escapes because of that negligence, the official can be jailed for two years.

sections.text: Whoever intentionally offers any resistance or illegal obstruction to the lawful apprehension of himself... or escapes or attempts to escape from any custody... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Resisting arrest or escaping from police custody is a crime punishable by up to two years in jail, in addition to whatever crime you were originally being arrested for.

sections.text: Whoever, intentionally offers any resistance... to the lawful apprehension of any other person... or rescues or attempts to rescue any other person... [punishment from two to ten years depending on the crime].
sections.simple: Helping someone else resist arrest or breaking them out of jail is a crime. The penalty increases to up to ten years if the person you helped was facing serious charges or the death penalty.

sections.text: Whoever, being a public servant... omits to apprehend that person or suffers him to escape... (a) if he does so intentionally... up to three years; (b) if he does so negligently... up to two years.
sections.simple: General punishment for officials who let people escape or fail to arrest them in cases not covered by other specific sections.

sections.text: Whoever... intentionally offers any resistance... to the lawful apprehension of himself or of any other person... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: General punishment (six months) for resisting arrest or helping someone escape in cases not specifically mentioned elsewhere.

sections.text: Whoever, having accepted any conditional remission of punishment, knowingly violates any condition... shall be punished with the punishment to which he was originally sentenced [for the remaining term].
sections.simple: If you are released from jail early on certain conditions (like parole) and you break those conditions, you have to go back to finish your full original sentence.

sections.text: Whoever, intentionally offers any insult, or causes any interruption to any public servant, while such public servant is sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Disrupting a court hearing or insulting a judge/official while they are working on a case is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, by personation or otherwise, shall intentionally cause... himself to be returned, empanelled or sworn as an assessor... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Pretending to be someone else to get on a jury or serve as a legal assessor is a crime punishable by two years.

sections.text: Whoever, having been charged with an offence and released on bail bond or on bond, fails without sufficient cause... to appear in Court... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Jumping bail: If you are out on bail and don't show up for your court date without a valid reason, you can be jailed for another year and lose your bail money.

title: BNS: Chapter XV. Of Offences Affecting the Public Health, Safety, Convenience, Decency and Morals
category: Offences involving public nuisance, spread of disease, adulteration, rash driving, and obscenity.

sections.text: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public or to the people in general who dwell or occupy property in the vicinity, or which must necessarily cause injury, obstruction, danger or annoyance to persons who may have occasion to use any public right.
sections.simple: A public nuisance is any act or failure to act that causes danger, injury, or annoyance to the general public or people living nearby. It also covers things that block or endanger people using public spaces.

sections.text: Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If you carelessly or illegally do something that you know could spread a deadly disease, you can be jailed for six months or fined.

sections.text: Whoever malignantly does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: If you purposely or with bad intent do something that spreads a life-threatening disease, the punishment is more severe—up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever knowingly disobeys any rule made and promulgated by the Government for putting any vessel into a state of quarantine, or for regulating the intercourse of vessels in a state of quarantine with the shore or with other vessels, or for regulating the intercourse between places where an infectious disease prevails and other places, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Breaking quarantine rules set by the government, whether for ships or for travel between infected and non-infected areas, is a crime punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever adulterates any article of food or drink, so as to make such article noxious as food or drink, intending to sell such article as food or drink, or knowing it to be likely that the same will be sold as food or drink, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Mixing harmful substances into food or drink that you plan to sell is illegal and carries a six-month jail term and a 5,000 rupee fine.

sections.text: Whoever sells, or offers or exposes for sale, as food or drink, any article which has been rendered or has become noxious, or is in a state unfit for food or drink, knowing or having reason to believe that the same is noxious as food or drink, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Knowingly selling spoiled or harmful food or drink is a crime punishable by six months in prison.

sections.text: Whoever adulterates any drug or medical preparation in such a manner as to lessen the efficacy or change the operation of such drug or medical preparation, or to make it noxious, intending that it shall be sold or used for, or knowing it to be likely that it will be sold or used for, any medicinal purpose, as if it had not undergone such adulteration, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Tampering with medicine to make it less effective or harmful while intending it to be sold as real medicine is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, knowing any drug or medical preparation to have been adulterated in such a manner as to lessen its efficacy, to change its operation, or to render it noxious, sells the same, or offers or exposes it for sale, or issues it from any dispensary for medicinal purposes as unadulterated, or causes it to be used for medicinal purposes by any person who has no knowledge of the adulteration, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Selling or giving out adulterated medicine as if it were pure is a crime.

sections.text: Whoever knowingly sells, or offers or exposes for sale, or issues from a dispensary for medicinal purposes, any drug or medical preparation, as a different drug or medical preparation, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: It is a crime to sell one medicine while claiming it is a completely different one.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily corrupts or fouls the water of any public spring or reservoir, so as to render it less fit for the purpose for which it is ordinarily used, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Intentionally polluting a public spring or reservoir so the water becomes unusable is punishable by three months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily vitiates the atmosphere in any place so as to make it noxious to the health of persons in general dwelling or carrying on business in the neighbourhood or passing along a public way, shall be punished with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees.
sections.simple: Polluting the air to the point where it becomes harmful to the health of people nearby is punishable by a fine of 1,000 rupees.

sections.text: Whoever drives any vehicle, or rides, on any public way in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Driving or riding a vehicle in a reckless or negligent way that puts lives at risk is punishable by six months in jail or a 1,000 rupee fine.

sections.text: Whoever navigates any vessel in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Operating a boat or ship recklessly so that it endangers others is a crime punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever exhibits any false light, mark or buoy, intending or knowing it to be likely that such exhibition will mislead any navigator, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Showing fake lights or signals to trick a ship's navigator is a serious crime that can lead to seven years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever knowingly or negligently conveys, or causes to be conveyed for hire, any person by water in any vessel, when that vessel is in such a state or so loaded as to endanger the life of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Transporting people for money in an unsafe or overloaded boat is illegal and carries a six-month prison sentence.

sections.text: Whoever, by doing any act, or by omitting to take order with any property in his possession or under his charge, causes danger, obstruction or injury to any person in any public way or public line of navigation, shall be punished with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
sections.simple: Causing an obstruction or danger in a public road or waterway is punishable by a 5,000 rupee fine.

sections.text: Whoever does, with any poisonous substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life, or to be likely to cause hurt or injury to any person, or knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with any poisonous substance in his possession as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Handling poison recklessly or failing to store it safely, resulting in a danger to others, is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever does, with fire or any combustible matter, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Reckless behavior with fire or flammable materials that puts lives at risk is a crime carrying a six-month sentence.

sections.text: Whoever does, with any explosive substance, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Being careless or reckless with explosives is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever does, with any machinery, any act in a manner so rash or negligent as to endanger human life... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Operating machinery recklessly or failing to maintain it safely is a crime punishable by six months in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, in pulling down or repairing any building, knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with that building as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: Being careless while demolishing or repairing a building, leading to public danger, is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: Whoever knowingly or negligently omits to take such order with any animal in his possession as is sufficient to guard against any probable danger to human life, or any probable danger of grievous hurt from such animal, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees, or with both.
sections.simple: If you fail to control your animal and it puts people in danger of serious injury or death, you can be jailed for six months.

sections.text: Whoever commits a public nuisance in any case not otherwise punishable by this Sanhita, shall be punished with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees.
sections.simple: General punishment of a 1,000 rupee fine for any public nuisance not specifically covered by other sections.

sections.text: Whoever repeats or continues a public nuisance, having been enjoined by any public servant who has lawful authority to issue such injunction not to repeat or continue such nuisance, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Ignoring a legal order to stop a public nuisance is punishable by six months in jail.

sections.text: (1) Whoever— (a) sells, lets to hire, distributes, publicly exhibits or in any manner puts into circulation, any obscene book, pamphlet, paper, drawing, painting, representation, figure or any other obscene object whatsoever; or (b) imports, exports or conveys... (c) takes part in or receives profits from... shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment... which may extend to two years, and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees...
sections.simple: Selling, distributing, or importing obscene materials (like books, drawings, or digital files) is a crime. First-time offenders face two years in jail; repeat offenders face five years.

sections.text: Whoever sells, lets to hire, distributes, exhibits or circulates to any person under the age of eighteen years any such obscene object... shall be punished on first conviction with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees...
sections.simple: Selling or giving obscene materials to anyone under 18 is a more serious crime, carrying a three-year sentence for the first offense.

sections.text: Whoever, to the annoyance of others— (a) does any obscene act in any public place; or (b) sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Performing obscene acts or singing obscene songs in public to the annoyance of others is punishable by three months in jail.

sections.text: (1) Whoever keeps any office or place for the purpose of drawing any lottery not being a State lottery or a lottery authorised by the State Government, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both. (2) Whoever publishes any proposal to pay any sum, or to deliver any goods... on any event or contingency relative or applicable to the drawing of any ticket, lot, number or figure in any such lottery, shall be punished with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
sections.simple: Running an unauthorized lottery office is illegal and carries a six-month sentence. Advertising such a lottery is punishable by a 5,000 rupee fine.

title: BNS: Chapter XVI. Of Offences Relating to Religion
category: Protection of religious feelings, places of worship, and sacred ceremonies

sections.text: Whoever destroys, damages or defiles any place of worship, or any object held sacred by any class of persons with the intention of thereby insulting the religion of any class of persons or with the knowledge that any class of persons is likely to consider such destruction, damage or defilement as an insult to their religion, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Damaging, destroying, or defiling a place of worship or a sacred object to insult a religion is a crime punishable by up to two years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, with deliberate and malicious intention of outraging the religious feelings of any class of citizens of India, by words, either spoken or written, or by signs or by visible representations or through electronic communication or otherwise, insults or attempts to insult the religion or the religious beliefs of that class, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Purposefully insulting a religion or its beliefs through speech, writing, signs, or digital communications to outrage the feelings of its followers is punishable by up to three years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily causes disturbance to any assembly lawfully engaged in the performance of religious worship, or religious ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Intentionally disrupting a legal religious gathering or ceremony is a crime punishable by up to one year in jail.
