sections.text: Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, or with the knowledge that the feelings of any person are likely to be wounded, or that the religion of any person is likely to be insulted thereby, commits any trespass in any place of worship or in any place of sepulture, or in any place set apart for the performance of funeral rites or as a depository for the remains of the dead, or offers any indignity to any human corpse, or causes disturbance to any persons assembled for the performance of funeral ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Trespassing in places of worship, cemeteries, or funeral grounds to insult a religion, or disrespecting a human corpse, is punishable by up to one year in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, with the deliberate intention of wounding the religious feelings of any person, utters any word or makes any sound in the hearing of that person or makes any gesture in the sight of that person or places any object in the sight of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Using words, making sounds, or making gestures in the presence of a person with the specific goal of hurting their religious feelings is punishable by up to one year in prison.

title: BNS: Chapter XVII. Of Offences Against Property
category: Crimes involving theft, extortion, robbery, dacoity, misappropriation, breach of trust, and cheating

sections.text: (1) Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person’s consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft. (2) Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both, and in the case of a second or subsequent conviction of any person under this section, he shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year but which may extend to five years and with fine.
sections.simple: Theft is defined as moving someone's movable property without their permission with the intent to take it dishonestly. The standard punishment is up to 3 years in jail; repeat offenders face at least 1 year and up to 5 years of hard labor.

sections.text: Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Stealing from a place where people live or where goods are stored (like a house, tent, or ship) is more serious and carries a punishment of up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If an employee or servant steals property belonging to their employer, the punishment is up to 7 years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft, or in order to the effecting of his escape after the committing of such theft, or in order to the retaining of property taken by such theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If a thief prepares to hurt, kill, or trap someone while committing a theft, escaping, or keeping the stolen goods, they face up to 10 years of hard labor.

sections.text: Whoever commits theft of any property from a person’s body or from his immediate possession, is said to commit snatching. (2) Whoever commits snatching shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Snatching is defined as theft specifically taken directly from a person's body or their immediate reach. It is punishable by up to 3 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property, or valuable security or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits extortion. (2) Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Extortion is forcing someone to give up property or money by threatening them (or someone else) with injury. The punishment is up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. [Theft is robbery if the offender causes or attempts to cause death, hurt, or wrongful restraint]. [Extortion is robbery if the offender is in the presence of the person put in fear and commits the extortion by putting that person in fear of instant death, instant hurt, or instant wrongful restraint].
sections.simple: Robbery is an extreme form of theft or extortion. It becomes robbery if the criminal uses or threatens immediate violence (death, hurt, or restraint) to commit the crime or escape.

sections.text: (1) When five or more persons conjointly commit or attempt to commit a robbery... every person so committing, attempting or aiding, is said to commit dacoity.
sections.simple: Dacoity is simply robbery committed by a group of five or more people. Every member of the group is considered a dacoit.

sections.text: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the robbery be committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, the imprisonment may be extended to fourteen years.
sections.simple: The punishment for robbery is up to 10 years of hard labor. If the robbery happens on a highway at night, the sentence increases to 14 years.

sections.text: Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Trying to commit a robbery, even if you fail, carries a sentence of up to 7 years of hard labor.

sections.text: If any person, in committing or in attempting to commit robbery, voluntarily causes hurt, such person, and any other person jointly concerned in committing or attempting to commit such robbery, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If anyone is hurt during a robbery (or an attempted robbery), everyone involved in the crime faces life imprisonment or 10 years of hard labor.

sections.text: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Committing dacoity (group robbery) is punishable by life imprisonment or 10 years of hard labor.

sections.text: If any one of five or more persons, who are conjointly committing dacoity, commits murder in so committing dacoity, every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If a murder happens during a dacoity, every single person in the group—even those who didn't pull the trigger—can be sentenced to death or life imprisonment.

sections.text: If, at the time of committing robbery or dacoity, the offender uses any deadly weapon, or causes grievous hurt to any person, or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt to any person, the imprisonment with which such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.
sections.simple: Using a deadly weapon or causing serious injury during a robbery or dacoity guarantees a minimum sentence of at least 7 years.

sections.text: Whoever, at the time of attempting to commit robbery or dacoity, is armed with any deadly weapon, shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years.
sections.simple: Simply being armed with a deadly weapon while trying to commit robbery or dacoity leads to a minimum 7-year prison sentence.

sections.text: Whoever shall be one of a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Being a member of a professional gang that regularly commits dacoity is punishable by life imprisonment.

sections.text: Whoever shall belong to any wandering or other gang of persons, associated for the purpose of habitually committing theft or robbery, and not being a gang of dacoits, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Belonging to a habitual gang of thieves or robbers (fewer than 5 people) is punishable by up to 7 years of hard labor.

sections.text: Whoever shall be one of five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Just meeting up with a group of 5 or more people to plan a dacoity is a crime punishable by up to 7 years.

sections.text: Whoever makes any preparation for committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Making actual preparations for a dacoity (like getting weapons or scouting locations) is punishable by up to 10 years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Criminal misappropriation is taking property that doesn't belong to you (like something you found on the street) and keeping it for yourself instead of returning it. This carries up to 2 years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use property knowing that such property was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of that person's decease, and has not since been in the possession of any person legally entitled to it, shall be punished with imprisonment... up to three years [seven years if the offender was a servant/clerk].
sections.simple: Stealing property from a dead person before their heirs can claim it is a crime punishable by 3 years, or 7 years if the thief was the deceased person's employee.

sections.text: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion over property, dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use that property... commits criminal breach of trust.
sections.simple: Criminal Breach of Trust (CBT) occurs when you are trusted with someone's property (like a bank or a friend holding a bag) and you dishonestly use or keep it for yourself.

sections.text: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: The standard punishment for breaking someone's trust and stealing their property is up to 5 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) Property, the possession whereof has been transferred by theft, or by extortion, or by robbery, and property which has been criminally misappropriated or in respect of which criminal breach of trust has been committed, is designated as 'stolen property'.
sections.simple: Defines 'stolen property' as anything obtained through theft, extortion, robbery, misappropriation, or breach of trust.

sections.text: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Buying or keeping something you know (or should know) is stolen is a crime punishable by up to 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, the possession whereof he knows or has reason to believe to have been transferred by the commission of dacoity... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If you buy or keep property that was stolen during a dacoity, the punishment is much harsher—up to life imprisonment.

sections.text: Whoever habitually receives or deals in property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Being a professional 'fence' or habitually dealing in stolen goods carries a sentence of 10 years to life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily assists in concealing or disposing of or making away with property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Helping someone hide or get rid of stolen property is punishable by up to 3 years in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces the person so deceived to deliver any property to any person... is said to 'cheat'.
sections.simple: Cheating is using lies or deception to trick someone into giving up property or doing something they wouldn't normally do.

sections.text: A person is said to 'cheat by personation' if he cheats by pretending to be some other person, or by knowingly substituting one person for another, or representing that he or any other person is a person other than he or such other person really is.
sections.simple: This is cheating by pretending to be someone else, like using a fake identity or posing as a famous person.

sections.text: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Standard cheating is punishable by up to 3 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property... shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: If you cheat someone specifically to make them hand over property or valuable documents, the punishment increases to up to 7 years.

title: BNS: Chapter XVIII. Of Offences Relating to Documents and to Property Marks
category: Crimes involving forgery, falsification of records, and tampering with ownership marks.

sections.text: A person is said to make a false document or false electronic record— (A) Who dishonestly or fraudulently— (i) makes, signs, seals or executes a document or part of a document; (ii) makes or transmits any electronic record or part of any electronic record; (iii) affixes any electronic signature on any electronic record... (B) Who without lawful authority... alters a document or an electronic record... (C) Who dishonestly or fraudulently causes any person to sign, seal, execute or alter a document... [knowing the person is unable to understand the contents due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or deception].
sections.simple: This defines 'faking it.' It covers creating, signing, or altering documents and digital records to trick people into thinking they are legitimate or authorized by someone else. It also includes tricking people who are drunk or mentally incapacitated into signing things.

sections.text: (1) Whoever makes any false document or false electronic record... with intent to cause damage or injury... or with intent to commit fraud... commits forgery. (2) Whoever commits forgery shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years... (3) [If used for cheating]: up to seven years. (4) [If used to harm reputation]: up to three years.
sections.simple: The basic rule against forgery. If you make fake documents to commit fraud or hurt someone, you can get 2 years. If you use those fakes to actually cheat people, that's a 7-year upgrade. If you just wanted to ruin someone's reputation, it's 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever forges a document or an electronic record, purporting to be a record or proceeding of or in a Court or an identity document issued by Government including voter identity card or Aadhaar Card... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Don't mess with the government's paperwork. Forging court records, birth certificates, or IDs like Aadhaar or Voter cards is a specific crime carrying up to 7 years in prison.

sections.text: Whoever forges a document which purports to be a valuable security or a will, or an authority to adopt a son... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment... which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
sections.simple: Forging high-stakes documents like wills, cheques, or adoption papers is a major offence. You could spend the rest of your life in prison for this, or at least a decade.

sections.text: Whoever has in his possession any document or electronic record, knowing the same to be forged and intending that the same shall fraudulently or dishonestly be used as genuine... [punishment based on the type of forged document].
sections.simple: Simply holding onto forged IDs or valuable securities with the plan to use them is a crime. The punishment matches the severity of the forgery itself.

sections.text: (1) A false document or electronic record made wholly or in part by forgery is designated a forged document or electronic record. (2) Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document... which he knows... to be a forged document... shall be punished in the same manner as if he had forged such document.
sections.simple: If you try to use a fake document as if it were real, the law treats you exactly like the person who forged it. Knowing better doesn't save you.

sections.text: (1) Whoever makes or counterfeits any seal, plate or other instrument... intending that the same shall be used for the purpose of committing any forgery which would be punishable under section 338... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or... seven years... (2) [For other forgeries]: up to seven years.
sections.simple: Making or owning the tools used for forgery—like fake seals or printing plates—is illegal. If the tools are for forging wills or money, the penalty goes up to life imprisonment.

sections.text: (1) Whoever counterfeits upon... any material, any device or mark used for the purpose of authenticating any document described in section 338... [punishment up to life or seven years]. (2) [For other documents]: up to seven years.
sections.simple: This covers faking security features like watermarks or authentication marks used on valuable documents. It's an elaborate way to get 7 years to life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly... cancels, destroys or defaces... any document which is or purports to be a will, or an authority to adopt a son, or any valuable security... shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or... seven years.
sections.simple: Purposely destroying or hiding someone's will or a valuable document to cheat them is treated as a top-tier crime, punishable by up to life in prison.

sections.text: Whoever, being a clerk, officer or servant... wilfully, and with intent to defraud, destroys, alters, mutilates or falsifies any book, electronic record... which belongs to... his employer... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: This is for employees who 'cook the books.' If you mess with your employer's records or accounts to commit fraud, you face up to 7 years in jail.

sections.text: (1) A mark used for denoting that movable property belongs to a particular person is called a property mark. (2) Whoever marks any movable property... in a manner reasonably calculated to cause it to be believed that the property... belong to a person to whom they do not belong, is said to use a false property mark. (3) [Punishment]: up to one year.
sections.simple: Using a fake mark to pretend someone else's stuff belongs to you (or vice versa) is illegal. It's a quick way to earn a 1-year prison sentence.

sections.text: Whoever removes, destroys, defaces or adds to any property mark, intending or knowing it to be likely that he may thereby cause injury to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Vandalizing or removing an ownership mark on property to cause someone trouble can land you in jail for a year.

sections.text: (1) Whoever counterfeits any property mark used by any other person shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to two years... (2) Whoever counterfeits any property mark used by a public servant... to denote quality... or passed through a particular office... shall be punished [with up to three years].
sections.simple: Faking someone else's property mark carries 2 years. Faking a government mark (used to show quality or that taxes were paid) is more serious and carries 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever makes or has in his possession any die, plate or other instrument for the purpose of counterfeiting a property mark... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Owning the 'printer' or stamps used to create fake property marks is a crime punishable by up to 3 years.

sections.text: Whoever sells, or exposes... for sale, any goods or things with a counterfeit property mark... [unless they prove they acted in good faith and shared where they got the goods]... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Selling items with fake property marks is illegal. You only get off the hook if you can prove you were tricked and tell the police who sold the fakes to you.

sections.text: (1) Whoever makes any false mark upon any case, package or other receptacle containing goods, in a manner reasonably calculated to cause any public servant or any other person to believe that such receptacle contains goods which it does not contain... shall... be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Tricking people about what's inside a box or the quality of the goods by using fake labels or marks is punishable by up to 3 years in prison.

title: BNS: Chapter XIX. Of Criminal Intimidation, Insult, Annoyance, Defamation, Etc.
category: Offences involving threats, public mischief, drunkenness, and defamation

sections.text: (1) Whoever threatens another by any means, with any injury to his person, reputation or property... with intent to cause alarm... or to cause that person to do any act which he is not legally bound to do... commits criminal intimidation. (2) [Punishment]: imprisonment up to two years, or with fine, or with both. (3) [If threat is to cause death or grievous hurt]: imprisonment up to seven years. (4) [If anonymous]: additional imprisonment up to two years.
sections.simple: Criminal intimidation is threatening someone (or their reputation/property) to scare them or force them to do something they don't want to do. Basic threats carry 2 years in jail, but threatening death or serious injury can lead to 7 years. Using an anonymous message to threaten someone adds an extra 2 years.

sections.text: Whoever intentionally insults in any manner, and thereby gives provocation to any person, intending or knowing it to be likely that such provocation will cause him to break the public peace, or to commit any other offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: Purposefully insulting someone to provoke them into starting a fight or breaking the law is a crime punishable by up to 2 years in prison.

sections.text: (1) Whoever makes, publishes or circulates any statement, false information, rumour, or report... (a) with intent to cause mutiny in the armed forces; (b) with intent to cause fear or alarm to the public whereby any person may be induced to commit an offence against the State or public tranquillity; (c) with intent to incite one class or community against another... [Punishment: up to three years]. (2) [Creating hatred between groups]: up to three years. (3) [If in a place of worship]: up to five years.
sections.simple: This covers spreading rumors or false information that could cause a military mutiny, create public panic, or incite different communities to fight each other. The punishment is 3 years, which increases to 5 years if the act is committed in a place of worship.

sections.text: Whoever voluntarily causes or attempts to cause any person to do anything which that person is not legally bound to do... by inducing or attempting to induce that person to believe that he or any person in whom he is interested will become... an object of Divine displeasure... shall be punished with imprisonment... which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
sections.simple: It is illegal to force someone to do something by making them believe they (or their family) will face 'divine' or spiritual punishment if they don't comply. This carries up to 1 year in jail.

sections.text: Whoever, in a state of intoxication, appears in any public place... and there conducts himself in such a manner as to cause annoyance to any person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to twenty-four hours, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both or with community service.
sections.simple: Being drunk in public and annoying others is a minor offence punishable by 24 hours in jail, a 1,000 rupee fine, or community service.

sections.text: (1) Whoever, by words either spoken or intended to be read, or by signs or by visible representations, makes or publishes in any manner, any imputation concerning any person intending to harm... the reputation of such person... is said to defame that person. (2) Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both or with community service.
sections.simple: Defamation is intentionally harming someone's reputation by making false claims about them through speech, writing, or images. It is punishable by up to 2 years in prison, a fine, or community service. The law includes several exceptions for true statements made for the public good or fair criticism of public servants and performances.
